reviewText:
Dead Space is pretty cool, I guess.

Set in the distant future of 2002, you play as Isaac Clarke, a man with two dads: Isaac Newton and Arthur Clarke. Unlike many Sci-Fi protagonists, Isaac is a space Engineer, which is like a normal Engineer but in space. And if EA promotional content is anything to go by, Isaac is also a golfer, a skateboarder, a mercenary, a world famous pugilist, and probably a really good kisser.

One day, Isaac and friends go to fix a bunch of broken stuff aboard the USG Ishimura, a ship that's literally named Rock Village". Unfortunately it does the opposite of make villages out of rocks and instead cracks planets open to eat the sweet sweet planet juice hiding inside. Ooh baby.  Unfortunately

Would highly recommend!

reviewText:
Dead Space is the unofficial Alien game we always wanted! The horrific plight of starship engineer Issac Clark aboard the U.S.G Ishimura perfectly replicates the feeling of isolation and suspense of Ridley Scott's classic, while also innovating and branching out on its own right to create an impeccable homage to sci-fi horror which continually surprises and rewards with each astoundingly well thought out design decision.

Immersion is everything to Dead Space. The complete lack of a standard HUD or in level load screens, inventory and menus screens that don't pause the game and the fact you are never taken away from Issac's perspective whether during gameplay or in menus, all combines to ensure you are never taken out of the experience. I have to commend the developer for what they have done with the HUD, placing standards like health and ammo counts not on a floating display but physically on the character and weapon at hand. It is one of the most original ideas I've seen in any game for years that takes something simple and makes it elegant, and taken as a whole this is one of the most atmospheric games ever released.

Gameplay is equally ingenious in that it takes something we know, in this case the shooting mechanics of a game like Resident Evil 4, and turns it on its head. Disregarding the tried-and-true aim for the head" mantra
date: you are required to dismember the tentacle like arms and legs of your enemies piece by piece
recommended: chopping them up into limbless husks in a concise and diligent manner conserving as much ammo as you can in the process. It's as gruesome as it sounds
hoursPlayed: but more than just an all out gore fest it lends a more strategic and thoughtful approach to combat that asks you to hold still and be precise with your shots in the midst of extreme peril
voteText: which gives it a feel all its own and playing other games afterwards starkly outlines how traditional many of them are in comparison.\n\nOf course none of this impromptu surgery would be possible without one of the best weapons in video game history: the plasma cutter. A tool of Issac's trade
helpfulPercent: it shoots a beam razor sharp plasma perfect for severing the many appendages of your foes
votesHelpful: and can be rotated for an even more exact cut. It's so good in fact that it actually forms one of my few complaints
votesTotal: as the other more rudimentary tools of destruction are far less interesting and practical to use
votesFunny: to the point I actively tried to avoid having to take them out. Thankfully after a few upgrades that became a very rare occasion
commentsCount: and the plasma cutter certainly is enough to make up for the lack of other useful weapons.\n\nDespite going on more than a half decade at the time of this review
column16: this is still an exceptionally good looking game which stands testament to how impressive it was to begin with. The environments are vivid and cohesive without growing sterile
column17: and the expert use of shadows is still unmatched by many more recent games. Reference quality sound design sells the experience
column18: almost demanding a high quality sound system or pair of headphones to fully appreciate. The plot never intrigued me in any great amount
column19: but like Bioshock before it much of the exposition is left in the form of audio diaries and notes which provided a great deal of backstory on the events before your arrival
column20: and help compensate for the otherwise lackluster narrative that only barely covers the typical video game chicanery of sending you to every corner of the ship in a rather contrived manner.\n\nOne final note isn't so much a con as simply something that should be stated. Despite its horror trappings Dead Space is still an action game first and foremost. After the first hour or so enemy patterns and scare tactics become easy to spot and predict
column21: which while not detracting from the experience may disappoint some hoping to be frightened out of their wits. That said it is still very apt at getting your pulse up through the ever constant gloom and tenseness of its atmosphere
column22: which even if it doesn't scare you should be more than enough to excite and increase your heart rate.\n\nFor anyone not turned off by the extremely graphic violence
column23: Dead Space is a must play. It excels at pulling you into its world and keeping you absorbed in it through an increadible atmophere that goes almost unmatched. With every step forward developer EA Redwood Shore (now renamed to the more fitting Visceral Games) show an acute knowledge of game design
column24: never content to reiterate something already done without making it their own

reviewText:
Pros
-Great atmosphere.
-Great sound design.
-Fun story and world.
-Very fun and satisfying game play.  The dismemberment is incredibly well realized.
-Monster design
-One of the best minimalist HUD.

Cons
-Can feel like one long fetch quest where everything goes wrong.
-Monster diversity.
-Running the game without vsync creates lights flickers due to the high frame rate at which the game runs on modern system. (fix by enabling vsync in the Nvidia control panel, in game vsync limit the game at 30fps)

Neutral
-Some of the mission objectives can become annoying.

Great game overall, highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

In Space no one can hear you talk
After a couple of hours of play, it would appear Dead Space is setting itself up to be the Ridley Scott's Alien of gaming. It almost succeeds to a point. Tense and fraught with danger, the suspense (coupled with the awesome sound design which truly heightens the atmosphere to harrowing levels) is almost unbearable at times. Every corridor you traverse holds some nasty alien surprise lying in wait to decapitate or gut you to pieces. The game sets up a fantastically eerie environment from the get-go and it feels like you live the game as you play it.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=339686702
Dead Space begins its tale after a distress signal is sent out by the USG Ishimura, a planetcracker" starship initially sent out on a mining operation by the Concordance Extraction Corporation. Taking on the role of engineer
recommended: you soon find yourself stranded on the Ishimura after a system malfuntion causes the ship you are travelling in to investigate the ongoings onboard the Ishimura
hoursPlayed:
crashes into its dock. The game uses a system of audio logs scattered around this "haunted house in space" to unfold the terryifing events that lead to the demise of most of the ships inhabitants.

Dead Space does not make use of the traditional heads-up display instead opting to offer you all the information you need via holographic projections emited from the gear that you wear. This keeps the screen clear and works fantastically by keeping you fully immersed in the horrors that begin to unfold once you board the ill-fated Ishimura.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=339686128
Being a survival horror don't expect ammunition to be lying around every single corner so the player needs to make sure that every shot counts when trying to take down these monstrosities. You can easily stock up on ammunition at the various shops set up around the spaceship but money is in very short supply and the ammunition itself is not cheap so often the player will find themselves in a situation where choices need to be made. Does one sacrifice extra ammo in favor of buying a medi-pack for healing or a node for upgrading weapons? This is not a game where you can have your cake and eat it.

I enjoyed the fact that Visceral Games chose to go for the amputating of various body parts to bring enemies down rather than the usual stock standard shot to the head that is the common norm in shooters these days. Where Dead Space unfortunately falters is with its clichéd story (an alien hive mind and artifacts form the backbone of the story). From a pure storytelling experience there is nothing new here that hasn't been told before countless times in other mediums.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=339687356
The gamer is left playing a mute protagonist
voteText: Isaac Clarke
helpfulPercent:
who doesn't say a word throughout the game to the various characters he comes into contact with which ultimately leaves him as one of those personality-less heroes that I found a bit difficult to rally around in the age of Commander Sheppard and Ezio Auditore.

Criticisms aside - the game is still a scarily good time with headphones cranked up to full and the lights turned off! The keyboard/mouse combo is a bit of a mess - you can see this is a console port through and through - but plug in a windows 360 controller and you are pretty much good to go.

reviewText:
Shoot the limbs and dismember them. That should do the job.

'Who Goes There?' — it's a science-fiction novella, written by John W. Campbell, which was adapted by John Carpenter as the 1982 famous film 'The Thing'. This phrase is well-suited as a slogan, which expresses all the essence of 'Dead Space' and emphasizes the outlines of its creators' intention.

This game has the full right to be a challenger for the status of most creepy, brutal, nightmarish and atmospheric third-person shooter with horror elements of all time. 'Dead Space' stands as a perfect example of the unity of well-thought-out Sci-fi setting and a sinister survival action. Here we've got spectacular, dramatic storyline, smart gameplay, innovative design and stunning soundtrack.

And although it's not 2008 now, but, perhaps, my review will encourage someone who hasn't yet been on the USG Ishimura decks to play this masterpiece.

10/10

reviewText:
Reasons why you should get this game

-This game has an amazing 80's sci-fi/horror atmosphere and storyline.
-Using stasis+the flamethrower is the most satisfying feeling in any game ever
-It manages to keep you on edge, yes there are jump scares, but I found that the most terrifying moment is not knowing what creatures you will be up against next or what your next mission will entail.

Reasons I would reconsider:

-Would suggest using a controller for this game simply because the camera controls are a little difficult to work with.
-The flickering lights don't really feel like they are flickering but more like the monitor is acting up (luckily there aren't too many scenes with flickering lights)

reviewText:
Yep, I'm 6 years late to the party with Dead Space, and even though it is that old, it still holds up well to being one of the most well-made games I have ever had the pleasure of playing. This is one of the few games that I was able to carry on straight into a second play through after finishing the first one.

This is a third person, action, horror survival game, and you play the ever mute engineer Isaac Clarke.

The scariness of the game is very much factor that dwindles as you play more and more. To begin with, every little noise kept me from turning a corner, but towards the end, the jump factor worse thin on most things.

Even though the game is 6 years old, it still looks absolutely stunning, giving you plenty of chances to show off that lens flare in screenshots.  The combat can seem very difficult to get to grips with at first, but I bloody love how each part of the aliens can just blow up and be removed from the

The game is locked at 30 fps until you turn off v-sync, which is on by default for some reason, although once you do turn  it off, your mouse controls become very slow and the only way I could get round this was by turning my DPI settings all the way up to max on my mouse itself.

All in all, Dead Space is one of the past decades classic must play titles.

Find more reviews at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

reviewText:
9/10
Overview: Survival Horror-Third Person Shooter

The Good:

+Graphics

+Lighting

+Atmosphere

+No HUD makes things more immersive

+I love that once you gain control of the main character, you never lose control, there are no cutscenes, cgi or anything that takes away control of the character. All the action takes place from the characters perspective and that provides an extra layer of immersion.

+The game provides a great sense of pacing, slowly introducing new enemies, gameplay mechanics, locations and puzzles to keep you second guessing what's around the next corner.

+Variety of weapons

+Finding nodes throughout the ship as well as purchasing it in the store allows you to upgrade your weapons and suit

+Combat, shooting limbs off enemies is satisfying

+Monsters look, feel and act scary along with good diversity to keep combat engaging.

+Variety of death animations

+Sound effects


The Average:

Disappointing last boss

The story can be very predictable

A few crashes


The Bad

- The game has some technical issues that you should be aware about specifically regarding vsync, mouse lag, frame rates. Turn off vsync to get the best possible experience.


Conclusion

This is arguably one of the best horror games to come out in the last decade. It does so many things right in the genre. I STRONGLY recommend this game to anybody who either loves survival horror games or third person shooters.

reviewText:
One of the best triple A titles I have ever played. You are Isaac Clarke, an engineer who has traveled to a Planet Cracker class ship to fix a communication relay, your motivation, the woman you love.

Things aren't so hunky dorey when you get there and what ensues is one of the best, albeit frustrating at times, survival-horror games ever made.

+The game still looks beautiful 6 years after release and there are plenty of opportunities for great screenshots
+Combat occasionally feels clunky but very satisfying when you dismember enemies
+Overall gameplay is good and rewarding
+Challenging boss fights
+Resource management is challenging but adds another level of gameplay to Dead Space
+When you complete the game you can start over with all of your items as well as some rewards for completing the game

+/-The plot, while the storyline itself is excellent, especially the twist at the end, some parts of the game are incredibly frustrating, e.g. 'Oh great you managed to find that thing which will save us! Oh but I just realised actually it won't be good enough, go find something else'
+/-Even medium difficulty is challenging at times, personally I like this but others may not
+/-Creepy enemies but not a particularly scary game especially compared to DS2

-Aiming while using matter cannons or while suspended by a 'large' necromorph is absolutely appalling even with a controller, very difficult to tell which way you need to move the weapon in order to get it in the right position
-Mouse controls aren't great and controller sensitivity can't be changed
-When using the steam overlay your normal mouse may appear in the game after using the mouse in the overlay
-No achievements

Verdict:
8.5

This is easily one of my favourite games and I'm so glad I played it to completion.

El K.

reviewText:
Intro
Welcome new recruit, hope you enjoy traveling through the emptiness and void of space as you traverse a deserted ship for signs of life that cried for help before their lives faded away.

Once again another game that is so horrific by the end of it I hope the main character just has common sense to ask for a pay increase.

Atmosphere
Dead Space is a great atmosphereic game that has alot of variety in enemies. While I did not find this game to be much of a horror" like how I think of Amensia I did find it to be a very good action-thriller.

Tools as Weapons
+ Weapons and Gear can be upgraded

Normally you would pick up a gun
recommended: however in this game you modify your tools to become weapons
hoursPlayed: each expressing its own style and functionality
voteText: constantly becoming powerful based how way you upgrade
helpfulPercent:
really helps  blowing off limbs from alien hordes.

Role as Engineer
+ Repairing sections of the ship varies

Playing as a engineer feels very aethentic
votesHelpful: repairing the ship
votesTotal: one section at a time feels not only rewarding but exciting
votesFunny: watching it come to life the further you go down the rabbit hole
commentsCount:
while upgrading your gear along the way to avoid being overcome by the monsters laying in wait.

Enemies
+ Good Variety of Enemies
+ Limb System adds dynamic ways to deal with enemy

There is a good selection of enemies and bosses to blow apart in this game. Brought me back to the days when games like doom had alot of variety in monsters. Their weaknesses being their limbs is also very interesting and somehow at the same time disturbing to a degree. A shame you cannot make any snowmen out of their limbs would be a real good scare for the children.

Conclusion
For those who want to play a game where you play as a engineer who goes through a isolated spaceship and blast the limbs off your enemy I do not know why you are still reading this.

Disclaimer: You might get so used to using tools as weapons that you go into your shed and modify everything into weapons and walk out like a berserker in a RPG fully geared to rock and load."

reviewText:
Great game from 2008.
Took me exactly 9 hours to complete story on easy with exploring almost every room.

reviewText:
This game was released in 2008 and I am playing it for the first time here in 2015.  I have to say this is a fan-freaking-tastic game.

Pros:
-Graphics and textures were amazing for an older game.
-The sounds and music in the game were fantastic. Made for some good scary moments. I jumped plenty of times.
-Great upgrade and progression path of weapons and items.
-Unique game physics and in game resource management.
-Loved the 3rd person perspective.
-Great weapon choices and secondary fire actions.

Cons:
-At times, felt a little repetitive and tedious having to always run back to the start to finish the missions.
-At times, camera angles and aiming were difficult in tight corridors.
-While the in game save feature is pretty unique, it got tedious constantly finding a save point and having to click through 3 screens to save.

Overall, I would give this game a strong 8.5/10.
I would highly recommend playing and picking it up on the next Steam sale.

reviewText:
I finally got around to this game. I played it bit by bit over time and it was quite enjoyable.

Although it's in the horror genre, I didn't find it to be too scary, instead it felt like a slower-paced FPS dungeon crawler in space, which was great.


I loved the theme of using engineering tools as weapons, and they made things interesting by making it more effective to dismember the enemies rather than just shooting for headshots or at the center of mass.


There are a few caveats though.

It is not a very good port. The mouse cursor feels terrible by default. You can fix the in-game mouse by locking the framerate to 60fps (see the PC Gaming Wiki[pcgamingwiki.com] for info) and use the keyboard for the inventory and menus.

I also didn't care for the default camera view, so increasing the FOV using the Widescreen Fixer app[widescreenfixer.org] helped a lot. I set mine to +0.31.


In all, it was a good game and I am looking forward to moving on in the series, hoping that a little more thought was put into the ports for the sequels.

reviewText:
Dead Space is a game that achieved instant classic status with me. An honorary spot on my shelf.

After finishing the game (which took me a while), I realized that the game had me on edge the entire time. And I mean the whole heart racing, eye wide open and sweaty palms deal.

This game is very and I mean very good at maintaining an atmosphere which keeps you on the edge constantly second guessing your every move and wondering what is around that corner, that vent, that elevator.

While steam only logged 30-ish hours of game play, I played my disk to death on my xbox. Literally, it has been run to the bare plastic film (May upload a screenshot later).

Graphics: 9.5/10
Sound: 10/10
Gameplay: 9.9/10
Atmosphere: 10/10

I can and gladly will expand on the details of the above four catagories if you are contemplating on purchasing this game. Just simply send me a friend request and I will gladly tell it all.

Bottom line: If you want to play a horror game set in deep space where no one can hear you scream, look no further for you've found the game.

reviewText:
Steven King, that very prolific author, delineates three types of fear. First is the gross-out, or disgust; the thing you want to get away from. The second is horror, the unkown; an aversion to things that you do not quite understand. And finally there is terror, the creepiness; when something is so close to being normal, but off by a tiny bit that makes it completely uncomfortable to look at. Dead Space wants to be scary, so it taps into all three fears. However, it ultimately relies more on disgust and the jump-scare than anything else.

Dead Space is a third person survival shooter set in space. You play Isaac Clarke, an engineer sent to repair the deep-space mining craft 'Ishimura'. Unfortunately, the ship is overrun with space-zombies called necromorphs and something really shifty is going on there so your job quickly becomes to get off that metal hunk before you're brutally murdered.

As mentioned earlier, Dead Space is more like a shooter than a horror game. The trope of horror is invoked, with the shadows creeping along the walls and monsters scurrying in the vents while you can only hope they don't jump you when you're looking the other way. When the horror subsides the gross-out takes over as the monsters are disgusting amalgamtions of bodyparts with claws where hands used to be and tentacles from every orifice looking to turn you into deli-meat if you don't shred them before they get in your face. Is the game terrifying at any time? Once, in a cutscene for a second or so, but when you do the math, Dead Space is a survival disgust shooter.

The reason why it isn't horror is because you get a good glimpse and understanding of your foes. The necromorphs all waddle toward you and they'll let you pick them off. Dead Space does not work quite like most zombie games. Necromorphs are completely unimpressed when you behead them. No, you have to dismember them; tear them limb from limb. This creates for some cool gameplay mechanics where you'll aim for the legs to slow them down and then tear their arms off to finish the job. Yet, some enemies require a more measured approach where you have to get around them or prevent them from falling in the first place, otherwise they'll spawn more trouble. Occasionally one will get the drop on you, but you're not scared of the creeps; you're spooked, anxious and thrilled, but not fearful. You're armed to the teeth to such an extent that you only really fear for your life, and that is classified as suspense.

Dead Space plays much like Resident Evil 4 and 5 in terms of controls. You aim with a laser pointer and use your ammo conservatively. You can use special powerups to slow enemies down or to throw the set pieces at them. You're a veritable slayer of monsters and everytime you gear up with new tools you start to look the part as well. What also helps the suspenseful atmosphere is the intergrated HUD. You don't have a screen overlay; your health and ammo are displayed on your character's model and interacting with the world is done in the same manner. It creates a keen level of immersion that not many shooters can attain.

When all is said and done, Dead Space makes good use of its atmosphere and lighting to build suspense and to release that tension at the best moments. You're on the edge of your seat, holding on for dear life as you fight off the hordes of disgusting creatures. Even the bossfights are a well measured and carefully calculated ordeal that keep you sucked in and fighting for survival without resorting to cheap set-pieces or quick-time events. Dead Space is an amazingly atmospheric thrill shooter that needs to played if only for its amazing presentation.

reviewText:
A classic example of atmospheric horror that will, surely, stand the test of time and remain as one of the best horror games,  and one of the best sci-fi games, I've ever played. I have a lot to talk about for this one kiddies, so grab some popcorn or something. I won't spoil anything for you either, so don't worry about that, if you haven't beaten the game yet


SOUND:
____
First and foremost: One of the most important pieces of any horror game is effective sound design. I didn't notice it as much on my first playthrough, sadly, because I only played in Stereo, but I went back recently and replayed the whole game in Surround Sound, high volume, with headphones, and oh boy, did I have a lot of pants to replace. Players aren't going to jump if a group of Necormorphs ambush them while the Betty Hill theme is playing in the background, likewise, the whispers you can hear throughout the ship wouldn't be as effective if they were accompanied by a vuvuzuela. In that sense, this game exceeds all expectations. They use just the right sound, every click, inhuman gurgle, and automated announcement falls so perfectly into place that you'll surely be looking over your shoulder.

Again, to experience this, play at high volume with surround sound headphones. I guarantee you, the difference in fear is like night and day. On my first playthrough with just stereo, that I did years ago, I didn't even flinch once at any scares, on my most recent playthrough, with surround sound, I cried at least five times.

The soundtrack is scary enough that even listening to it out of the game makes me feel like I should be on edge, looking over my shoulder. Beautiful composition, that fits perfectly with the world established by the game.

The sound aspect of Dead Space scores a 10/10 from me. Suberb job, every audio-design student should play this at least once to see how much of an effect using sound correctly can have on a person's experience. It's the difference between confidently strolling down a corridor and hesitantly walking down it, moving your legs oddly as your legs are soaked in fear-urine.
____

GRAPHICS:
___

By graphics, I don't mean 'oh look how high-definition this texture is!

recommended: what I mean is how appealing a game looks

reviewText:
Dead Space is an action oriented survival horror game.
You are Isaac Clarke, an engineer that is part of a rescue team. Your mission is to repair the spaceship USG Ishimura, a huge mining vessel that carves out chunks from planets and harvests the valuable ore. Shortly after they arrive on board all hell breaks loose. Their craft is destroyed, leaving them stranded on the Ishimura. The crew is attacked by nightmarish creatures. Seperated from the others it is up to Isaac to wander the halls, search for any friends or survivors that are still alive and fix as many problems as he can until he can find a way to escape the ship.
The setting is where the game shines. It definitely feels like you are in deep space. There are sections in a vacuum, things sound differently as you would expect if you were in an airless environment. You also have a small air supply that will run out if you are not quickly. There are other parts where there is no gravity and you can leap from floor to ceiling or walk up the sides of a wall.
A cool aspect is that there is no HUD. Health is displayed on the back of your suit and ammunition is displayed when you hold up your weapon.
Another interesting feature is the holographic screens that appear throughout the ship and when someone is talking to you. All elevators and doors have one of these screens instead of a standard switch.
The graphics are good. It has great lighting effects, textures, and models.
The sounds also really help with the immersion. You will sometimes hear random clanking, footsteps, or alien grunts and shrieks that keep you on your toes. The music gets intense when you are under attack by a group of aliens and is kind of spacey when you are just exploring alone.
Overall, if you like blood, gore, horror and action you should try Dead Space. There might be too much action in this game for the old school survival-horror fans but it should still be ok for them.

Sounds 9/10
Graphics 9/10
Gameplay 9/10
Atmosphere 10/10

If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

reviewText:
Dead Space is a survival horror game. You are slow moving with jump out and scare you moments. The character Issac controls slow and clunky. Plus your character Issac Clark takes up a lot of the screen, which I guess happens in a lot of over the shoulder shooters. You want to see what's behind you. Since this is an over the shoulder shooter, things can easily sneak up on your left side, even more so than behind you.

The game drips with atmosphere, horror and gore, but it doesn't feel scary. Maybe I'm just used to horror games, or maybe its the fact when you run through a dead enemy, you kick it like a soccer ball and it flops like a rag doll fish. That's probably why Doom 3 had its dead enemies burn into nothing. With Dead Space, the idea is that enemies can still be alive... when they look dead. The game looks awesome and makes great use of lighting and shadow. You won't be in dark areas so much as dim areas with lights shining through vents. It has a great look to it.

Dead Space boasts strategic dismemberment, such as first cutting off a leg of an enemy, before you cut off its head. If you cut off its head, it will blindly swing at you. If you cut off its leg, it will crawl and lunge at you. Most enemies are like this. Other enemies might explode with smaller, more annoying enemies if you're inaccurate. There are also reanimating enemies that take priority, because they'll monsterfy every dead body in the room. So if you're the type of gamer that likes aim over put more bullets into it, this game is for you! The enemies will even work their way through vents if you've gone to another room and they'll pop out. The vents are pretty easy to spot, but a lot of vents are on the ceiling.

There are four major weapons in the game, the line cutter, flame thrower, plasma rifle and some sort of saw gun. It is unfortunate that you'll end up primarily using the weapon you start with for the entire game. That feels like a wasted opportunity. The flame thrower feels extremely weak if not completely useless.

You're able to collect items, like health, ammo, air canisters for when you're walking in space and its all contained in your limited inventory. When you upgrade your 'rig' (suit), you can carry more stuff, but for the most part, since everything is sellable, you'll rarely run out of room. As the game starts, there is plenty of ammo, but at around six hours in, ammo gets scarce, but you can still buy more. Lack of ammo comes from missing vulnerable points of enemies and having them explode into smaller points.

You'll also pick up node modules to upgrade things and if you start upgrading your line cutter, then why would you ever switch to a different weapon? Plus, any ammo that you get for other weapons, you can just sell at one of the game's stores for credits that you can use to buy more line cutter ammo. There are locked rooms that you can use a node to get into, but since nodes are one of the most valuable and costly items in the game, it might not be worth the risk to see what's in the mystery room. You'll also be able to explore and find items in cabinets, lockers and smashable boxes, but you really can't wander too far off the beaten path.

Traversing the USG Ishimura feels like there is plenty of back tracking, with some getting lost. Luckily there is a 3D slightly difficult to use map. For the most part, each level is contained into branching segments, you'll start at the root of the map tree, clear out one branch and all of its limbs, end up at the root / hub of the level, then go for the next branch area. Sadly some of the 'chapters' reuse levels. The USS Ishimura is a big space ship, and I would call it similar to Metroid-Vania-ish since you'll revisit areas of a ship, but its all broken into 'chapters' that you can't return to unless its in the storyline to return to that section.

There are some puzzles, but nothing major. You'll get powers like telekinesis to move objects and a slow down stasis to solve puzzles and get through areas. Without the puzzles, the game seems easy even on normal difficulty.

The game has a very painful key binding system, especially for lefties. While you can rebind keys, you can't rebind all keys, so I recommend just using a controller. The controller works great and has simple controls for a complex system. You've got buttons for run, inventory, aim, stomp (to downed enemies and boxes), melee attack (which seems useless), use button and the D-pad will call your 4 weapons to switch. When you're aimed at something, you can reload, fire your weapon. alt-fire, use telekinesis or stasis to slow anything down.

Thankfully save points and checkpoints are everywhere. It keeps the game progressing, but another negative of the game is when you run out of ammo or health and just can't pass a section, you're locked into that section. When you're stuck, you've got two choices, run all the way back to a store at the start of a level, or sometimes you might just have to restart from a save point. This is why I can understand EA's desire to throw micro transactions into the game. If you get stuck with no ammo, no credits and only have 1 save file, you might literally have to restart the game. When you get 10+ hours in, that will kill your desire to play.

In all, the game feels good to play, despite how slow it is. If you enjoy typical space horror with the plot of Aliens, this game is for you! The game has been $5 on Steam and free on Origin. Chances are if you wait, there will be a sale, a bundle or a free download.

reviewText: One of the greatest horror games of the last generation, for sure. Dead Space builds up suspense and tension, using a sci-fi environment, a creepy atmosphere, and lots of blood. You play as engineer Isaac Clarke, who goes on a routine mission to repair a damaged spaceship. Obviously the mission isn't so routine, and it's up to Isaac to find his girlfriend Nicole and escape with the rest of his crew. The enemies are known as the Necromorphs - humans who have changed into hideous creatures. Over the course of the game you will find new weapons, armor, and upgrades to help you along the way. Just be sure to stop playing the series at two; Dead Space 3 is a whole new kind of monster...

reviewText:
TL;DR: Intense sci-fi horror with great atmosphere and solid gameplay mechanics; an old gem that still holds its own.

For a player that was never interested in survival horror Dead Space was still attractive due to its setting and premisis. Having played it a long time ago on console and now revisiting it on PC, this game is still fantastic for old and new fans of the genre.

Positive features:
-Genuine horror elements
-Satisfying gun play with a different range of weapons and upgrades
-Graphically impressive and well optimised
-Interesting story with detailed backstories found in game
-Good UI and item management system

Negative features:
-Occasional backtracking

To conclude Dead space is a great game with a combination of horror and action, a classic, that deserves a play for any fan of survival horror and even new comers who are brave enough to try it.

reviewText:
Overall score = 8/10

Dead Space is a wonderful game combining many genres, third person shooter, survival, action, and horror, all into on. While some games fail when trying to do too much, Dead Space is able to do all of these parts well and deliver a satisfying experience from start to finish.

Dead Space progresses very nicely from start to finish. The story is intriguing and, while horrifying space creatures is nothing new, presents a well rounded and detail/lore filled experience that took some thought to follow. The opening sequence leads very nicely right into the action, immediately making you want to find out just what happened to that ship.

As far as firefights go, this game offers some intense sequences. Whenever I overcame a hoard of enemies I felt like a badass, but I always hoped that an engagement like that wouldn't happen again. This may be what Dead Space does best: present you in an environment that makes you uncomfortable, leave you feeling exposed at all times, and give you just enough to get the job done if you do it right and think on your feet.

That being said, I found the biggest flaws in the game to also center around the combat situations. While there are plenty of action sequences in the game, it is not as smooth as other action games, which is of course fine as this isn't the initial purpose. However, some sequences and enemies felt cheap to me when you meet them. The enemies are varied, challenging, and interesting as a whole, but some sequences are downright frustrating. Often this happens when an objective is not fully clear or your purpose is not adequately explained. I don't expect a game to hold my hand, but when it isn't clear what that button you just pressed does, but swarms of enemies come out of the vents, it can become exhasperating. Fortunately, this doesn't happen too often.

The progression system in Dead Space is very good and rewarding. You can build your loadout to your playstyle and upgrade equipment to suit your strengths. Dead Space offers a variety of weapons to use and tactics to implement to keep battles fresh and fun.

I would definitely recommend Dead Space, even though it is a few years old. It is still a great game, and at a discount during Christmas or summer for $5 simply can't be missed.

reviewText:
Dead Space is a good ride through a pretty scary ship. Packed with jump scares. The monsters are straight out of the 80's movie “The Thing”, with almost an Event Horizon style of design to the ship. There is a nice leveling up system, and there are some interesting weapons. There is even some Zero G action, which was a nice touch. The game does have a frustrating part at the end of chapter 4, but before you rage quit put down your 360 controller and grab your gaming mouse (solves the problem trust me). Dead Space is definitely one to buy on steam sale if you haven’t played it. The game being older runs well on a most systems (not your grandmas Windows 95, but anything from 2012 and up should be fine). The only thing that could have made this better would be some co-op, but it may have killed some of the atmosphere. Turn off the lights, crank up the volume, and get ready. Here it comes!

reviewText:
Dead Space to me is like Super Mario 64 to my Nintendo machine.  I don't know how and why the Dead Space series has slipped over the years, but Dead Space 1 was always the best Dead Space and a genre defining game.  In fact, no one has really created a game where there are space zombies, you fight these things in space, combined with scare and horror with the dread of being alone.  You are truly alone in space.

Dead Space 2 was great too but no where as near as great as Dead Space.  It's one of those games that left an imprint in my recollection of gaming experiences along with Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, Super Mario 64, Street Fighter, Goldeneye 64, Lost Odyssey, Valkyria Chronicles, Halo series, and a few others.

The Dead Space Universe is where the heart is.  There's vast potential.  The world of Dead Space is intriguing, and when well written, developed, and executed, it's the definitive space zombie game with a major twist.  But to call it space zombie is a hit from the hilt.  It's a lot more than that.  They're called necromorphs, and they're terrifying.  Horrific.  They terrorize your soul.

The premise of Dead Space is overwhelming with potential possibilities that could bring the series back to life.  Dead Space 4, if it happens, will hopefully revisit the memories of the first game.  It's a must-play, sit in a dark room, with your headphones on video game.  Immerse yourself fully into its atmosphere and it will be one of the best times you've spent playing a game.

Rating: 9.2 out of 10

reviewText:
It's like you were dropped off in a horror movie. The fear will consume you. Your heart will pound after being jumped on when you least expect it. That fear will make you into a heartless machine that will anticipate any attack from any corner.

You see that dark corner over there? Definitely going to be jumped there, you think to yourself. You think to yourself that you are the master of horror and know what will happen. You play several scenarios in your head of different actions to take when you get to that corner as you walk over with your gun drawn, anticipating a jump. Nothing.

Paranoia is a sign of insansity, my friend. You will not escape this world as the same person you were when you entered.

reviewText:
Well, first of all, let's say, that entering Dead Space universe is kinda risky, because it can hold you for a looooong time.
Dead Space is a some kind of masterpiece for me. I played it alot on pirated version, when i didn't even have a Steam, so don't pay too much attention about play time, just replayed it one more time on the hardest difficulty.

So, what is this game?
- First of all. NECROMORPHS! Yus, they are the key feature of this game, you will love them alot. They are very, very interesting, funny, lovely, and cute. But to be honest, ugly as hell, and sometimes Ishimura reminds hell really nice.
- Atmosphere. It has amazing sounds, scenes, and environment. Just don't forget to listen to sounds a little more, and you will feel yourself uncomfortable.
- Effort, length. Dayum, this game is longer, than 50% of our time's horrors. And very, very well made. Reading and listening to every note is making a wonderful feeling of very deep atmosphere.
- Great OST. I don't have any words for it. Had a feeling, that actually it's not a music, but real sounds.

Why i didn't say anything negative about game?
Because... Urgh, don't even know. I don't think, that this game has something to let people ragequit, except jumpscares.

Well. I'm giving to it 10\10, beause it's playable unreally good in our time too.  Graphics are good enough. xD

reviewText:
Dead Space remains my all time favourite game. Replayed it over and over on X-Box, love it so much I got it on PC too. In this game you play as an engineer called Issac Clark and is set far far into the future out in Space.

It definately does not lack a horror element and has a very very very good storyline. Play this game with headphones and you will appreciate Viscerals attention to sound details. Metal clashing, electricity buzzing, necromorphs (The monsters) moving around in vents, Issac's breathing, screams - all out horror noises.

The graphics are good. Most of the game is quite dim to create the horror element. LIghts and sparks of electricity add to an array of lighting effects.

You have a great choice of weapons which can be upgraded in-game by collecting powernodes. I love how you have in-game currency and literally do not have to spend real life money at all.

PLAY IT before Dead Sppace 2 & 3 - otherwise the story won't make much sense, plus it's by far the best in the trilology.

Dead Space - ruining my life since 2008

reviewText:
When it was released in 2007 I remember Dead Space being one of the best horror games I had played since the Silent Hill 2/Fatal Frame CB-era. Going back how does it hold up today? A bit on the good, a bit on the bad it seems.

First off know that if you like horror games and have never picked up the series then there’s really no reason not to play the game. Despite some of its shortcomings it’s still a deeply immersive experience. Though I think the series as a whole gets lauded as “thah scuriest games evurh!” far too often (as you’ll eventually become used to its brand of trying to scare you and begin predicting where the next enemy is coming from) that doesn’t change the fact that the environments are excellently crafted, deeply foreboding, and the gameplay is fun if not perfect.

In fact while I believe the later games certainly improved on the mechanics, and I eventually grew to like Isaacs voice (he’s silent in this one), I think overall this game creates a far better atmosphere. You rarely if ever feel safe, the graphics while aged still look nice, and unlike the later entries unless you’re playing on the easiest difficulty or two (or are a horror god) you’ll be rationing supplies to an extent. Additionally while some dislike it I quite liked the fact that except for a few rare occasions almost all communication with others is done via radio, true it isn’t as cinematic as later entries, but it gives the distinct impression that only you can save yourself and no help is coming. It’s true that thanks to an upgrade system most people do feel rather powerful by the end, but you have to work toward that and in the early to middle game it’s true survival horror.

As for the bad, well as I said later games improved on the mechanics and that’s because some of the mechanics are broken. The big mechanic of “shoot the limbs” is completely missed by the inclusion of weapons that can do just as much damage shooting for the core (it can be fun to play through with only the base weapon and it is perfectly effective, but isn’t required and if you’re just breezing through can totally be skipped). The Zero-G sections are awe inspiringly painful to play, you’ll get the hang of it but because you have no control and can only jump from point-to-point it isn’t fun. And the physics are all over the place as well as the hit-boxes at times, especially where stomping or some of the more concentrated weapons are concerned.

There’s also a small factor that never really bothered me but I see brought up all the time so it’s worth mentioning. This game truly is “fetch quest, the FPS”. Though the underlying plotline, the history, and the environment of the ship itself are all very interesting the actual activities you’re asked to complete aren’t. EVERYTHING is broken and because the other survivors are a bunch of sissy pants you literally get to fix a starship as a one-man engineering crew. The fact that the other elements are so strong glossed over this for me, but lots of people note it and I can’t deny its truth.

In short the game is still a classic. Some of it hasn’t aged as well as other parts but like great horror games from the very start of gaming chances are you’ll easily forgive those things in light of the overwhelming positives.

reviewText:
Just finished Dead Space on Medium (Normal) difficulty. So far the title has been an absolute thrill, with tension and terror at every turn, some physical and some psychological. The backstory of the game is very deep, with you being able to control the character Isaac in an attempt to escape a ship  filled with the undead alive, preferably with his allies and his wife, who is lost onboard. The background is explored through lost recordings, some video, audio, and text, as well as the environment itself.

The title itself is very unsettling, as even bumping into a beer can will startle you. Undead can appear behind you, in front of you, above you, all around you. It was fairly challenging on medium, with an option for Easy, Hard, and an unlockable Impossible mode, which I haven't tried out yet. Items can be found through schematics, bought in the store, and then upgraded through the use of nodes (items which you insert into others to make them better). The story is long, around 8-10 hours if you spend time collecting everything. The replayability factor is large enough for maybe 1 or 2 extra playthroughs, which can be spent using your fully upgraded arsenal, or upgrading it to that, and collecting logs you may have missed.

The downsides to this title are mentionable, although they don't detract from the experience very much. No steam achievements, cards, or DLC for this title. I cling to hope that EA may port their dlc to the pc, preferably in a package, although its small. I encountered a glitch, which I read is very common for pc gamers. That glitch is called the Continue glitch"

reviewText: Haven't gotten around to finishing it yet but, if you like scary games, this is definitely the one for you. While it does have some jump scares, like many games of this type do, it doesn't rely on them in any way, shape, or form. Dead Space is all about ambiance. Almost no matter where you go, there's deep dark shadows where things can lurk, twisted and broken scenery from past struggles, gaps in the walls, ceilings, and floors so that you can see the creatures crawling between walls and into vents. Then there's the sound. At all times there's the sounds of loose metal clanking, echoes of transmissions being broadcast and some of the eeriest music you'll find on a game. All of this combines to engender a feeling of constant anxiety while playing.

reviewText: Dead Space is a First Person Shooter-Horror game where you arrive at a Spaceship which has ceased communication and must figure out what has happened to the crew. You make your way through various levels of the ship and learn about the horrors that have taken place, while fighting a variety of creatures who have infested the ship. The learning curve is fairly decent and the game is fun on the hardest settings for the experienced FPS'er. Graphically speaking the game looks pretty good, the lighting is fantastic and adds to the thrill and horror of the gameplay. Dead Space is a good game to purchase and has been successful enough to spawn sequels

reviewText: Dead Space provides one of the most interesting stories I have ever heard. A heavily immersive third person horror with a well developed story, as well as unique characters and enemies alike. Weapons and pick-ups are a topic in game that can make your brain think. Health is a vital thing, so you need to think about what med packs you should carry; small, medium, or large. You also must make room for ammo, as you might run out of that in only two rooms! Once you have planned out your inventory space, you can now take in the atmosphere-or not. Incredible sound system and atmosphere has you on edge in every location. When those lights turn out, so do the sounds for a brief moment. Then...BAM! Roar! This kind of encounter brings the chills down your spine like no other! Last but not least, is the story. To be honest, the story was the true reason I kept playing, as every chapter kept getting more and more interesting. If you want a scary game to play loud and proud on a dark and stormy night, this will be a keeper.

reviewText:
***I originally wrote this review on 11-04-2008***

Creating a successful horror game is tricky. There needs to be just enough of a blend tension, fear and scare tactics so the game does not fall to mundane generic enemies jumping out at players. Dead Space not only creates the one of the best atmospheres in a horror video game, it’s full of enough puzzles, frights and dilemmas to make even the most jaded 3rd Person Shooter player sit up and take notice.

You play as Isaac Clarke, a space engineer, traveling to the USG Ishimura, a “Planet Cracker” which is emitting a distress call. After a tense opening sequence, Isaac boards the ship with his coworkers, Lt. Zach Hammond, security officer, and Kendra Daniels, a computer expert, and soon realizes this is no ordinary distress call as the ship has been overrun by an alien race. Isaac gets separated from his coworkers and must fight his way through the alien monsters to bring the ship back online and find a way off the Ishimura.

Gameplay:

Dead Space has taken every great piece of third person gameplay in the history of video games and combines it together to deliver an entertaining, enjoyable journey. You navigate Isaac from an over-the-shoulder view. There is no Heads Up Display (HUD) in Dead Space. Your health is indicated by the light meter embedded in the spine of your suit spine. Your ammo is displayed above your weapon when you aim and your stasis meter is also located on the back of your suit. What is stasis? It is a piece of technology that gives you the ability to slow down objects and enemies for puzzle solving and reaction time. You can recharge your stasis by accessing stations located throughout the ship or by finding portable stasis packs. Isaac also has the ability to use Kinesis, which allows him to move heavy objects or acquire objects that are out of reach. Stasis becomes available to Isaac a few minutes into the game, and Kinesis becomes available for use when entering the second chapter and has unlimited use.

The game's most unique and striking appeal is operating in zero gravity or a vacuum. When entering a Zero-G zone, Isaac has the ability to jump from one side of the area to another. This opens up an new realm of puzzle solving and is some of the most fun sequences in the game.

The enemies in Dead Space are deformed humans that were killed and turned into monsters by a race of alien creatures. There are a dozen or so different styles of enemies that navigate their way through the ships ventilation system, which means you may encounter an enemy at any given time. As many enemies as there are, they all can be taken out with the same technique: begin by shooting off their limbs first. Direct hits to the body will waste ammo, especially during fights with the tougher, more advanced enemies. Some of the more memorable enemies are the epic boss fights that also combine a little Zero-G action. The threats on the ship are sometimes not always enemy related. Dead Space shifts gears twice for a little Han Solo, “Don’t Get Cocky” turret action.

So how do you take out all the enemies? With a wide range of weaponry of course. Isaac begins the game with a Cutter, an extremely accurate “laser” that fires a wide beam either horizontally or vertically. There are tons of lockers and chests to explore during the course of the game. Some lockers may contain ammo and others may contain credits, which can be used in Stores. At these Store locations, Isaac can store, ammo and items. Isaac is limited in the number of items he can carry, however the number of items can be increased if he upgrades his suit. Usually near by a store, is a Workbench, where Isaac can upgrade his weapons and gear.

There is a lot of backtracking in Dead Space. At the beginning of each chapter, Issac exits a tram which carries passengers from one section of the ship to another, and at the end of each chapter he makes his way back to the same tram to journey to the next section of the ship. Isaac visits some sections of the ship more than once. There are tons of save points throughout Dead Space, probably more than there should be. Even if you don not save, Dead Space autosaves so much that you really do not have to save once through the entire game, unless you want to exit out of Dead Space or turn off your PS3. To make the game even easier, the developers also added in a feature that actually maps out the direction Isaac needs to travel to complete his next objective. This feature is displayed by a blue outline on the ground. (see pic below)

The problem that most avid gamers will notice is that everything, aside from the zero gravity gameplay, has been borrowed from past films, novels, or other games. The over the shoulder view bares a striking resemblance to Resident Evil 4, the monsters are mere replicas of John Carpenter's The Thing, parallels in Event Horizon are seen throughout the entire game including some obvious set design rip offs and features in Doom 3 and System Shock are also used in Dead Space. It is at this point where we stop and think: are these references by the EA Readwood Game designers an homage to their favs or are they simply thefts? No matter, the similarities are not enough to take away from the Dead Space experience which delivers a terrifying story, but the influences are definitely obvious.

Graphics and Sound:

Dead Space does everything right graphically. It looks beautiful in full 1080p when staring out into the vast ocean of space, blowing an enemies head off, or playing through some beautiful level designs of what a 'Planet Cracker's' engine room, maintenance bay and mining section may look like.

The sound effects are also top notch in Dead Space. As Isaac communicates with his team, a 2D holograph image appears before Isaac, which the player can rotate. The static overlaid onto the video and audio logs is incorporated nicely, and the creeks and cracks heard throughout the broken ship add much to the atmosphere. Listen for the lullaby.

Players may pick up quickly on how Visceral tries to scare its players. They use the same formula that Hollywood does, during a tense or critical moment in the game they play loud music like the typical brass pieces you hear in most horror movies. More often than not this takes place when a player looks in the direction of an enemy. So this tactic may help a player in certain areas rather than scare him or her. If a player is not paying attention and some random horns start playing, that is a pretty good indication that there was probably a monster that ran past the door that they probably missed.

Pros: controls work extremely well on the PS3, terrifying boss battles, graphics and sound are gripping,

Cons: : unoriginal enemies, predictable but engaging story, very easy to beat, lots of backtracking

Bottom Line: I recommend this game in spite of my criticism of the unoriginality of some of its elements but it is defendable to question why this game has been so highly touted. Some have labeled Dead Space as the ‘Worlds Scariest Game’ and people are shouting from roof tops to “Buy this game immediately!”. The game isn’t perfect, but what is? It has a wonderfully smooth flowing story, a great environment, near perfect controls and graphics that can make a grown man cry. Dead Space is solid game that should be experienced by as many players as possible. There are striking resemblances to a dozen pieces of work, but they are forgivable. Expect a sequel.

reviewText:
A hugely intense game marred by a bad case of consolitis. Dead Space spawned a whole host of imitators, and for good reason -- it's well-made and placed in a setting original enough to make it stand out from most third-person shooters. Great atmosphere, exceptional surround sound, and ingenious weapon design combine to make a game worth playing through to the end.

Unfortunately, Dead Space suffers from some of the worst console-to-PC translation I've ever experienced. ♥♥♥♥♥♥ gamepad controls make movement and aiming more painful than they need to be, and there's a hardware conflict that can cause the gamepad to do nothing but spin the camera in a 360° pattern (something that the devs never bothered to fix through the entirety of the series, amazingly enough). The unchageable FOV prevents me from playing for more than a couple hours due to motion sickness. There's also a bug that causes stuttering when vsync is enabled.

The positives definitely override the negatives though, and Dead Space is a game that should be experienced by horror aficionados and shooter fans alike.

reviewText:
Personally, this is the best survival horror game I have ever played, even beating out Resident Evil 4 which is also amazing.  Everything about Dead Space is great, you will not find a better atmosphere in any survival horror game, the sounds you will hear and shadows you will see skittering across your screen will keep you in suspense for the majority of the game and while there are jump scares, the majority of the horror is definitely thanks to the sound effects and atmosphere.

Our silent protaganist is Isaac Clarke and you can definitely tell that he's not your everyday hero but an engineer sent to the USG Ishimura just for simple repairs..................wrong! Necromorphs of death! YEAH!

I highly suggest you play with the lights off and use a headset and see what survival horror is truly about.

15/10 Dead Space.

reviewText:
A terrifyingly good TPS game. Dead Space - I believe - reinvented the genre and showed that there were originals games at the time. I liked both its sequels - yeah, the 3rd part has more action, so what? The story continues, so this was needed so those of you who prefer the scary parts can easily play the first game again.

Pros:
--- hologram-like ingame menu: your inventory, the map, and even your objectives are projected in front of you
--- the concept of dismemberment: forget everything you learned from FPS games - headshots this time will not work, at all
--- amazing graphics and equally high-quality audio: my favourites are the zero-g scenes where you hear your breathing more than the surrounding sound
--- high replayability due to the unlockable items, difficulty modes

Cons:
--- not much to say here, really, perhaps that the game can be difficult at times, but not because it truly is challenging but because fighting in close-quarters can only be difficult (you cannot really come up with any proper tactics)

The sequels only improve upon the experience by expanding upon the story and giving the protagonist a face and voice.

reviewText:
There are few bad things I can say about this game. It has unskippable cutscenes and dialog. Some of the weapons just ain't great. That's about all. What's left is a thrilling experience and engaging gameplay.

You will be fighting corpses twisted by a mysterious plague on a mining ship orbiting an alien world. You will not be a soldier though. You will be a space handyman. Against all expectations, you will be the only hope against this inhuman evil and your weapons will be your tools for the most part.

Really I want to leave it at that so you can discover the horrors as Issac, the player character, does.

IMPORTANT NOTE: I didn't play this for the longest time because the mouse is super laggy without some tweaks. I'm talking a good second to acknowledge my movements. It is fixable. Search google. It's something to do with the V-Sync implementation. You can override it through your video drivers.

reviewText: This game is a wonderful addition to anyone's horror library.  Dead Space brings a truly gruesome and unsettling atmosphere into humanity's near future, and provides an experience which at times makes you suck in your gut in fear of death, and at other times makes you feel at home as you stare into the quiet peace of space.  The third person over-the-shoulder gameplay style is similar to that of Resident Evil 4 and 5, leaving Isaac as a relatively slow but powerful tank with the ability to run when he needs to escape certain death.  It is a game that will make you question what the right" decision is as you unravel more of the games dark story which is driven by conspiracy

reviewText:
One of the creepiest games I've ever played. This is mainly due to the feeling of loneliness that you have troughout the game. Isaac reminds me of Gordon Freeman from Half Life: the lonely hero.

reviewText:
This game is just straight up, no doubt about, 100% fact, awesome. It's also poop your pants scary. The graphics are very dark and detailed, which fits the game just right. The storyline is gripping, extremely intense, and, well, scary! Did I mention this game is super scary?
Anyway, the game manages you to put yourself into the main characters shoes very well, even though Isaac Clarke, the man you play as in the game, does not talk, which something very few games manage to do.
The gameplay is very gory, violent, and fun. I'd have to say this is one of my favorite games I played this summer, and I have to say, I don't like a lot of scary games!
So in conclusion, Dead Space is just plain awesome, and I look forward to playing Dead Space 2 and 3. If you're looking for a game that is scary, but at the same time, has a great storyline and epic mechanics, then this game is for you.

reviewText:
Ceaseless jump scares and savage dismemberment. That's what this game promises which it provides to varying degrees of success. Everyone's different but it didn't take long for me to understand the game's formula enough to not be fazed by the scares. Atmosphere trickles but it doesn't surge out and suffocate you in all it's crimson glory which is disappointing, really. Ammo being scarcer would have helped build the tension as even on the hard setting you're basically Scrooge McAmmo-Man.

To combat the spacebeasts you're provided with a myriad of weapons, of which you can carry up to 4 at any given time. You can switch them out at HUBs though I only found 3 of them satisfying to use. Along with the weapons you get a couple of cool abilities which work well in harmony. Despite the pointless CQC, I found targeting limbs and blowing stuff up very fun. You also get some cool looping level design which works well in this environment and an interesting story.

From a technical side it isn't the most proficient game out there. Cadavers tend to randomly bug out and just writhe around uncontrollably which will likely scare you more than the scripted scares. More importantly some game breaking bugs exist where the only cure may be to restart the game so save often and on multiple save files! As Nevermore didn't once say it's a Dead Love in a Dead Space. Play it anyway!

reviewText:
Excellent game, very moody and very creepy. Finally a new IP that takes horror seriously.
It gets more action oriented about halfway through though, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing as the atmosphere will still be tense. The menus also integrate well into the gameplay without pausing the entire game so you have to keep on your toes at all times.

Since the game takes place in space the graphics are a bit futuristic, but still dark.
The voice overs are very good (your character doesn't speak though) and the sounds are just amazing.
If you love horror games, make sure this is on your 'to play' list., I guarantee you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: I found it unplayable on PC. Mouse aiming AND controller aiming are both worthless. Disabling vsync will only fix the lag and 10fps menus and 30 fps gameplay, which then leaves you with massive obvious tearing because half this game uses strobe lights. It will not fix the massive deadzone in your aiming. There's no analog to the aiming, or very little. You either dont move, or you turn full speed. Maybe I'm just picky but this is ridiculous. Just get the sequel. It has a nice summary of the first game for you and improved lots of aspects of the game.

reviewText: If you've been living under an asteroid for the past decade, this is a really, really frightening game. It is very atmospheric, one of the games selling points. Oh and the soundtrack doesn't do anything to help calm the nerves. The gameplay is a bit linear, though this isn't essentially bad, as this unleashes a majority of the game's scares. The weapon range is amiable, although most players will be satisfied with the plasma cutter.The story is fairly cluttered, although the mysterious origins behind the Ishimura is welcome ambiguity. The graphics and art direction are both effective and coherent, in particular the gorgeously horrific character models. Although the enemies do get a bit repetitive, the developer's reasoning behind intensifying things through plotting you against overwhelming quantities is...refreshing. This is an excellent horror shooter, with the only flaws being its lack of enemy and weapon variety and its linearity. Oh, and look behind you.\n\n8/10

reviewText: I've heard good or bad things about this, in my opinion though this is a very ingenious little survival horror that actually manages to deliver plain out startling as well as subtle scares, the feature to re-visit areas that you had already been to, in later chapters, and find actual changes there and to virtually go anywhere on the spaceship that you're on made this a quite unique experience. It's also immersive, due to how ingame inventory system and other info screens are implemented, and the combat is frightening as well as fun. For something that EA has published, this is actually very good in my opinion.

reviewText:
By far one of the greatest shooters ever. And I don't mean just survival shooters, I mean shooters in general. One of the few games that has a story that doesn't once seem to drag along.
Although you can probably run through the whole game without once giving the story a thought I found it pretty appealling.
Action-wise, keeps you at the edge of your seat all the way. The best horror game I played as of yet with some people saying they culdn't even play it.
On the replayability side of things it does offer unlockable difficulties and also lers you play it as New Game+ with the same difficulty but adding bonuses.
All in all , I'd give it a 9.5 cause I don't believe in 10/10.

reviewText:
This game is badass. Believeable sci-fi setting combined with great character performances, intriguing story, inescapable atmosphere, solid gameplay, and some of the best sound design I've ever seen.

The enemies also make really good use of using body horror as a mental attack on you.

Man this game is gewd. Only fault is probably making your character a bit too much of a badass, and the weapons a little too effective, making the latter half of the game a real breeze once you got some decent upgrades and cash behind you.

reviewText: A classic already, Dead Space is one of the most fun horror games I've ever played. You must roam the ravaged hulls of derelict space ships looking for a way to escape back home, before the hordes of necromorphs (zombie mutants, essentially) kill you. The unique (at the time) twist? The best way to kill any of these monsters is by dismembering them one limb (or two) at a time using your Plasma Cutter and other futuristic power tools! Lots of fun, good jump scares, and a serviceable plot all tie together into a really good time. Just be sure to turn Vsync on... or off.. I forget which, if your mouse controls are lagging. Just swap it to whatever it isn't set on already.\n\nIf you're considering buying the double pack with Dead Space 2, do it! Dead Space 2 is a lot of the same gameplay with more polish and is still a blast, especially if you liked the first. Stop there though, Dead Space 3 is an abomination and should never have been made.

reviewText: Dead Space is the most tense video game I have ever played. Bar none. The graphics are solid, the sounds are creepy, and the silence is sometimes scarier than the jump scenes. The story isn't anything to write home about, but the journey through Dead Space is worth it time and time again.

reviewText:
Back when Dead Space first came out I was really not interested in it. I initially thought it was just a modernized System Shock 2 ripoff. When I play it now I don't really see that. It's actually more Resident Evil 4 in space.

You play as Isaac Clark and you're sent with a bunch of engineers to repair this one space ship yadda yadda yadda insert Alien reference here. One thing I should mention about Dead Space is it's a very polished game. The graphics and engine still hold up relatively well, and the lack of heads up display is fairly immersive. The storyline leaves something to be desired but like every game in this genre it has good audio logs.

At the very least Dead Space still retains good value for money to this day, and if you enjoyed Resident Evil 4 this will appeal to you greatly.

reviewText:
Despite having a lot of issues, Dead Space is still fun to play. It is not an amazing title by any means, but it gets the job done (barely).

The Good:
- The atmosphere is definitely the selling point of Dead Space. It is executed perfectly and it really conveys the feeling of Oh God... what happened to this place?"
- The story is somewhere between ok to good depending on your perspective. I don't think it was an amazing story though.
- Good characterization (minus the main character ironically).

The Bad:
- The combat is relatively oversimplified. There is no crouching. There are no stealth mechanics. There is no "take the high ground for an advantage" type of feeling. Tactical fighting is not present in Dead Space. Your goal during encounters is to dismember your enemies by destroying their limbs instead of aiming for their torso or head. Enemies are "leashed" to rooms
date: so if you find yourself in a tough fight all you have to do is step through a door and they cannot follow you. This really trivializes the game as you can bypass many enemies this way.\n- The location of your health bar is for some reason attached to your character (Dead Space is third-person). While this  looks cool
recommended: it does not work well in combat. For example
hoursPlayed: if you are backed into a wall by a group of opponents
voteText: you can no longer see your health bar and you have no idea how much damage you have taken.\n- As a port to PC
helpfulPercent: the controls are not fluid. Turning and moving around is not completely smooth. I had to adjust the mouse sensitivity multiple times in certain areas because it was so difficult to move. Also
votesHelpful: while using the Store Console
votesTotal: there is no mouse cursor present to select items you want to buy from the list. You cannot scroll through the list with your mouse wheel. You have to manually use the arrow keys to scroll and choose your items. How can something as simple as a mouse cursor for a list of items not get implemented?\n- I found it very strange that the character you play as (Isaac) never says a single word the entire game (literally
votesFunny: he says nothing). Other characters even stop to ask you questions and talk to you but Isaac never responds. I find it hard to connect with a mute character. Also I think it's very important to connect with the main character so you care about what happens to him/her
commentsCount: but with Isaac presenting zero personality or speech
column16: it is very difficult to care about him.\n- Considering how unique the enemies are that you fight
column17: I would have thought EA could have created some very cool boss fights or interesting mechanics. The boss fights though were massively disappointing and not interesting.\n\nOverall
column18: Dead Space is carried by it's perfectly executed atmosphere and well-paced horror gameplay. The game is actually pretty good
column19: but the unresponsive controls and a couple of poor UI choices are noticeably detrimental.\n\nAs a side note
column20:
the story (not the gameplay) of Dead Space and the way it unfolds is scary similar to System Shock 2 (probably 85% of the concept of Dead Space is the same concept as System Shock 2). System Shock 2 is a far superior game to Dead Space though in terms of both gameplay and story (I feel awful even using them in the same sentence).

Dead Space takes about 12-15 hours to complete.

7/10

Please upvote this review if you found it useful :)"

reviewText:
The game with the unique ambiance, a thrilling and hidden story. The game where you get disturbed. This game is, and perhaps will be for a long time, my favourite game series. Why?

Let me start with a concise summary of the story.
Basically what happened in the Dead Space universe, is that mankind is on the brink of extinction due to lack of resources on Earth. Desperately, humanity reaches for space and launches the biggest project involving planet crackers; huge spaceships with gravity tethers able to crack open planets in order to harvest it from useful resources under its surface. One of the planetcrackers has gotten into Aegis 7. The solar system has been marked as restricted and therefore the planet cracker USG Ishimora went on an illegal operation, as the planet might carry exceptionally portions of minerals and raw materials. A colony was established to maintain the mining operations. During these operations they discovered an alien artifact called The Marker"
date: a religious cult believe that it holds the key to humanity's redemption and a way to heaven. However
recommended: the project leaders of the mining operation were mostly interested in the Marker's ability to create infinite energy. Days after the discovery both the colony and Ishimura go dark. A small repair crew was dispatched to check the issue out. This is where you drop in
hoursPlayed: you experience the story behind the shoulder of Isaac Clarke (3rd person perspective)
voteText: an engineer as part of the repair crew. You discover the disasterous and morbid events the Ishimura goes through as you try to escape the Ishimura
helpfulPercent: which is now filled with alien incarnated human corpses.\n\nThe atmosphere in this game is absolutely amazing. They managed to keep you thrilled throughout the whole game by using variety of fear inducing events
votesHelpful: a well-balanced range of space and room (from tight corridors to giant engine rooms)
votesFunny: background
commentsCount: SFX). The story is appealed from the very beginning and still obsesses me this very day. A collection of unlockable weaponry
column16: upgrades and armor keeps the game rewarding as well as video and audio logs
column17: which reveal parts of the background and main story. The sequels of Dead Space (Dead Space Extraction
column18: Dead Space 2
column19: Dead Space 3
column20: the Dead Space animes and so on) are wonderful as well
column21: but the first game bears something unique. After your first playthrough you'll be filled with nostalgia
column22: because your first experience of this game will be engraved in your soul."

Well, what can I say about this Video Game. It has lots of big spooky monsters. They look like something out of Grandpa's medication induced nightmares.

The game has stellar features that even Grandpa can figure out, first there is a stomping feature that allows the main character to open crates on the ground, inside these crates are Arthritis Medicine and bullets for the main gun which shoots lasers (I wish we had this back when we were fighting those damned krauts). The game is very long, almost as long as it takes me to get the channel clicker to move to the next one.

This game seemed to cater well to Grandpa's growing Alzheimers, it seems to tell what is going on whenever.

What was I talking about again? Oh yes, I believe this nickel is for you, Billy...but don't tell your father I gave this to you, he might put me in a home.

(laughs)

Grandpa is always proud of you, Billy. Stay in school.
