reviewText:
I enjoyed this game. It is scary... if dead bodies scare you. I mean, ..sure there are moments where I jumped a bit, but..scary is ..giving it too much credit. Perhaps how I played (as a paranoid person I shot all bodies, removed all corpses from rooms before fully entering them, had plenty of ammo at all times with all weapons, kept aware of all surroundings and exits, etc) maybe I killed the scary..but ...whatever.

Its good. Good gameplay, good story, good characters, great environments. Even good puzzles / level design.

What's wrong is that... its not scary, its just incredibly gore intensive. Its piles of flesh and blood here, constant disgusting dismemberment of reanimated alien dead things..and ...I was grossed out. Half the time I was supposed to be scared of something I was more worried how gross it was going to be to kill it.

The game has some great moments though that are worth the money to experience. A good buy.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Originally posted on May 13, 2011

Event Horizon, Pandorum, Alien, even 2001. All of these films and many other great Sci Fi traditions act as a healthy source base for Dead Space. The game features a distress call, a seemingly silent ship which we quickly realize is dark and full of monsters. Something has gone terribly wrong.

The game's carefully crafted atmosphere and surprisingly good voice acting are really what draw you in. Although the plot is very transparent, and the character development (especially for Kendra) is a little weak, the game isn't really about that. It's about living out some version of the space horror fantasy you've had in your head ever since the first time you saw say, Event Horizon. The game has it all, spooky lighting, creepy cultists, a wide array of frightening monsters, and a slowing unfolding backstory involving a typical breakdown of the chain of command and descent into chaos.

Playing this game with headphones and in the dark, while alone, even a second time through, is quite an experience. Your heart will pound and you will jump out of your seat.

Graphically speaking the game isn't much to look at, and the necromorphs aren't very inspired in their design, although they are scary. Nevertheless, the lighting and audio more than make up for the game's low resolution textures and low poly models.

Apart from really wonky object physics, the game feels very good to play as well. The slow turning speed of Isaac, your avatar, contributes to the sense of the game as being about horror/survival, and scavenging is essential. You aren't incredibly vulnerable, especially after upgrades, but you feel like you are, and that's what counts.

Ultimately, Dead Space is a surprising and fun guilty pleasure of a game that will remind you of nights spent watching sci-fi horror movies scaring yourself senseless in the dark.

Wow.

This game. Imagine going on a walk at 2:34 AM with a few of your buddies. Now imagine you're being chased by undead things that run FAST and can potentially chop you in half. Now imagine you're not with your buddies. And you're in space. And you have a box cutter.

This game is phenomenal. I loved it! If you're comfortable with shooters and want a bit of a challenge go with hard, otherwise go with medium difficulty. The story is gripping and horrific. Sound is flawless. Ambience is perfect. This game truly is terrifying and very well put together.

reviewText: A classic already, Dead Space is one of the most fun horror games I've ever played. You must roam the ravaged hulls of derelict space ships looking for a way to escape back home, before the hordes of necromorphs (zombie mutants, essentially) kill you. The unique (at the time) twist? The best way to kill any of these monsters is by dismembering them one limb (or two) at a time using your Plasma Cutter and other futuristic power tools! Lots of fun, good jump scares, and a serviceable plot all tie together into a really good time. Just be sure to turn Vsync on... or off.. I forget which, if your mouse controls are lagging. Just swap it to whatever it isn't set on already.\n\nIf you're considering buying the double pack with Dead Space 2, do it! Dead Space 2 is a lot of the same gameplay with more polish and is still a blast, especially if you liked the first. Stop there though, Dead Space 3 is an abomination and should never have been made.

reviewText: A combination of Doom 3 and Resident Evil. The game won't bring you down to your knees, but still is quite enjoyable. Not as scary as D3,  it occasionally is. If you have some spare time and want to play a decent (but not an extraordinary) horror shooter, then that's your game.

reviewText:
I'm going to try to summarize the dead space experience.
Slowly lose your sanity in a creepy atmosphere, face horrific monsters that require precision to kill, in an extremely frantic environment. Whispering voices in your head, Is anyone really alive or are you just imagining it?

Seriously now, Dead space is a quality survival horror game, if you aren't careful your ammo will run dry and you'll be in big trouble, the jumpscares are there... but they're rare and far in between. The game changes pace in just the right places to keep you guessing what'll happen next. The story is simple, you crashed into the USG Ishimura and are trying to get back home. The characters you interact with are alright, some of them are there just to tell you what to do, then theres some that run the mad scientist trope, but all their lines are well written and the actors deliver with high credibility. If you have an old computer there wont be a problem, dead space's PC port is excellent and allows a smooth framerate with impressive visuals, not just for an old game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Despite having a lot of issues, Dead Space is still fun to play. It is not an amazing title by any means, but it gets the job done (barely).

The Good:
- The atmosphere is definitely the selling point of Dead Space. It is executed perfectly and it really conveys the feeling of Oh God... what happened to this place?"
- The story is somewhere between ok to good depending on your perspective. I don't think it was an amazing story though.
- Good characterization (minus the main character ironically).

The Bad:
- The combat is relatively oversimplified. There is no crouching. There are no stealth mechanics. There is no "take the high ground for an advantage" type of feeling. Tactical fighting is not present in Dead Space. Your goal during encounters is to dismember your enemies by destroying their limbs instead of aiming for their torso or head. Enemies are "leashed" to rooms
date: so if you find yourself in a tough fight all you have to do is step through a door and they cannot follow you. This really trivializes the game as you can bypass many enemies this way.\n- The location of your health bar is for some reason attached to your character (Dead Space is third-person). While this  looks cool
recommended: it does not work well in combat. For example
hoursPlayed: if you are backed into a wall by a group of opponents
voteText: you can no longer see your health bar and you have no idea how much damage you have taken.\n- As a port to PC
helpfulPercent: the controls are not fluid. Turning and moving around is not completely smooth. I had to adjust the mouse sensitivity multiple times in certain areas because it was so difficult to move. Also
votesHelpful: while using the Store Console
votesTotal: there is no mouse cursor present to select items you want to buy from the list. You cannot scroll through the list with your mouse wheel. You have to manually use the arrow keys to scroll and choose your items. How can something as simple as a mouse cursor for a list of items not get implemented?\n- I found it very strange that the character you play as (Isaac) never says a single word the entire game (literally
votesFunny: he says nothing). Other characters even stop to ask you questions and talk to you but Isaac never responds. I find it hard to connect with a mute character. Also I think it's very important to connect with the main character so you care about what happens to him/her
commentsCount: but with Isaac presenting zero personality or speech
column16: it is very difficult to care about him.\n- Considering how unique the enemies are that you fight
column17: I would have thought EA could have created some very cool boss fights or interesting mechanics. The boss fights though were massively disappointing and not interesting.\n\nOverall
column18: Dead Space is carried by it's perfectly executed atmosphere and well-paced horror gameplay. The game is actually pretty good
column19: but the unresponsive controls and a couple of poor UI choices are noticeably detrimental.\n\nAs a side note
column20:
the story (not the gameplay) of Dead Space and the way it unfolds is scary similar to System Shock 2 (probably 85% of the concept of Dead Space is the same concept as System Shock 2). System Shock 2 is a far superior game to Dead Space though in terms of both gameplay and story (I feel awful even using them in the same sentence).

Dead Space takes about 12-15 hours to complete.

7/10

Please upvote this review if you found it useful :)"

reviewText: In terms of horror these days, zombies seem to be a key mechanic in attempting to instill fear in the player. Naturally, with so many people harboring a fear of death and the unknown, a creature that comes back from the dead is a remarkably effective means of accomplishing and setting a fear-striking atmosphere. But with so many games applying this mechanic, it does tend to become broken and repetetive, leaving the recipient jaded and unamused.\n\nTo help add a new spice to the genre is Dead Space, a game whose name will take on numerous meanings throughout your playthrough. reviewText: I've heard good or bad things about this, in my opinion though this is a very ingenious little survival horror that actually manages to deliver plain out startling as well as subtle scares, the feature to re-visit areas that you had already been to, in later chapters, and find actual changes there and to virtually go anywhere on the spaceship that you're on made this a quite unique experience. It's also immersive, due to how ingame inventory system and other info screens are implemented, and the combat is frightening as well as fun. For something that EA has published, this is actually very good in my opinion.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game. It is scary... if dead bodies scare you. I mean, ..sure there are moments where I jumped a bit, but..scary is ..giving it too much credit. Perhaps how I played (as a paranoid person I shot all bodies, removed all corpses from rooms before fully entering them, had plenty of ammo at all times with all weapons, kept aware of all surroundings and exits, etc) maybe I killed the scary..but ...whatever.

Its good. Good gameplay, good story, good characters, great environments. Even good puzzles / level design.

What's wrong is that... its not scary, its just incredibly gore intensive. Its piles of flesh and blood here, constant disgusting dismemberment of reanimated alien dead things..and ...I was grossed out. Half the time I was supposed to be scared of something I was more worried how gross it was going to be to kill it.

The game has some great moments though that are worth the money to experience. A good buy.

reviewText:
A nice horror 3rd person shooter action game that is Resident Evil + Silent Hill, in space.

Similar to Resident Evil and Silent Hill, you play in 3rd person mode killing aliens with your various guns while scavenging for loot. Unlike the previous 2 games, you can actually buy items such as ammo from stores which are located throughout the game. You can also strategically shoot off body parts of aliens to damage them more, allowing you to conserve ammo.

The graphics and sounds are good. The story is decent enough, though story was never a forte in this game genre.

The con is that there are too many moments where aliens suddenly appear in your face, scaring you through sudden shock. So if you have a heart condition, do not get this game. But if you don't, consider getting this game while it is cheap.

reviewText: This game is quite the terrifying single player adventure, and is intensely creepy playing by yourself in a room devoid of any light but from your computer monitor. You get that feeling of horror for your protagonist practically everywhere you go because you're not exactly certain what to expect next. You will soon learn to fear for the life of your digital protagonist after witnessing one death animation. Especially since you are isolated from the small crew you arrived with for the majority of the time. You will encounter torrid creatures that threaten the lives of you and your crew. You will be seperated from comforting human contact or support for substantial lengths of time. Your mission will take you to a massive mining vessel whose crew of roughly thirteen-hundred strong has disappeared".\n\nFirst and foremost
date: you must survive using problems solving techniques and careful application of defensive resources. If you succeed
recommended: you will uncover the truth as to what happened on the mining vessel and the events that transpired before the collapse.\n\nThis title is now on my recurring list of games to play as the years go by
hoursPlayed: and I'm quite certain the sequels will be as well."

reviewText: This is one of my favourite games. The designers, artists, and developers at Visceral Games (formerly Redwood Shores) just nailed it perfectly.\nThe whole idea of the universe, the atmosphere, the story, the location, the main character, the enemies, the weapons, the graphics and sounds, the TPS view, the HUD"; basically I feel that everything about this game is in the right place.\nI think you're a fool if you skip this (and don't forget that you need to play it on the hardest difficulty)! :)"

reviewText:
This game is right around 7 years old now, but I am just now playing for the first time, and boy do I love it. The combat is not anything special and is a little slow paced, but that really isn't anything to complain about. The game looks damn good considering how old it is, but the best part about the game is the story. I really like the setting and atmosphere of the game. I enjoy finding the audio/video logs that explain the lore even further. The game does a good job pacing itself and I am always intrigued to find out what will happen next to the characters and how it will turn out in the end. The game itself really isn't all that scary, just with some cheap jumpscares and all, but is rather creepy and eerie. I think this is one of the best horror games in the past decade.

The actual port of the game is decent. After the Vsync change that fixed a gamebreaking bug the game plays just fine. I personally use a wired 360 controller because I just wasn't a fan of the default key layout and did't want to deal with the mouse sensitivity/acceleration problems. Other than those 2 issues I have had no other problems.

I give Dead Space a solid 9/10

reviewText:
I decided to have another run through of this gem over Halloween - I've owned various copies on various platforms over the years but figured it might as well refresh my memory from my first playthrough back in 2008.

For a horror fan, this game is a must. The atmosphere this title manages to evoke is amongst some of the best I've ever come across in my 20-year gaming career. If you're a fan of The Thing, Event Horizon, Alien, anything along those lines, you will *relish* the game's mixture of music, storytelling and pace. The fact that I've just finished my god-knows-how-many-th run through here in 2015 having thoroughly enjoyed every minute really underlines how well the devs did.

The game does like it's share of jump scares but I found it didn't overdo them - rather than go down Doom 3's route of continuously letting loose horrors from hidden cabinets, half the time the game lets your own head do it's work for you - you'll glimpse things rushing down corridors, you'll hear whispers in the dark without any clear source, every so often something will clang and crash. It's classic horror stuff of messing with your head to make the reveal all the better. The game drip-feeds it's story by way of audio logs, footage, and gradual exposition across what used to be a place where it's crew worked and lived, as you slowly learn what the f*** happened on this doomed ship, and the excellent voice acting really pushes the script in the right direction.

Technically, it's a fairly standard third-person shooter - much of the ruckus about how your character is an average blue-collar Parker-from-Alien engineer thrown into a nightmarish ghost ship crawling with horrific entities is fairly thin, as your 'improvised engineering tools' can be turned into shockingly devastating instruments of destruction (quite what a miner needs a giant particle cannon for is explained as, um, shooting rocks... yeah, makes you wonder how fast and ferocious rocks are in the future) but none of that is really important - expect a gameplay pace sitting somewhere between Mass Effect 1 and Gears of War with *very* rough narrative outline and atmosphere similar to System Shock 2. Intially playing like a Survival Horror, padding down corridors with a palpable feeling that you are only alive by sheer luck with precious little kit, the game steadily becomes more and more action-packed with Isaac the Engineer undergoing some serious nerd rage, upgrading his contraptions to fight ever more gross and numerous monsters that take leaves out of pretty much every sci-fi horror of the last 20 years.

But don't play this for the simple gameplay, as entertaining as it is. Play it to enjoy a truly awesome sci-fi horror and wish that the gaming industry produced half as much as this stuff as it did CoD clones.

Then play it's sequel. Like me. :D

reviewText:
A nice horror 3rd person shooter action game that is Resident Evil + Silent Hill, in space.

Similar to Resident Evil and Silent Hill, you play in 3rd person mode killing aliens with your various guns while scavenging for loot. Unlike the previous 2 games, you can actually buy items such as ammo from stores which are located throughout the game. You can also strategically shoot off body parts of aliens to damage them more, allowing you to conserve ammo.

The graphics and sounds are good. The story is decent enough, though story was never a forte in this game genre.

The con is that there are too many moments where aliens suddenly appear in your face, scaring you through sudden shock. So if you have a heart condition, do not get this game. But if you don't, consider getting this game while it is cheap.

reviewText:
I will make it short, there's plenty great reviews of this masterpiece out there.

I love scary, intriguing innovative FPS/TPS games. Of course, it's not that easy to get spooked for me.

This game can make your heart race and then it rips it out! It is worth every dollar you pay for it. I fully recommend it.

If you like games that have great story, very innovative and non-linearly behaving enemies that will surprise you sneaking around to get to you. When you like shooting scary, disgusting, mutated monstrosities coming at you and not being able to just shoot them up" in a blind rage - but having to precisely target them. And each enemy needs a different tactic + you need to utilize your choice of 4 guns throughout the game to the fullest - then this is a game for you. It also has some really cool - and usually interrupted by tons of enemies... logical puzzles to solve tho most of them aren't that tough to crack.

I rarely have time to play these days. But this game was a beautiful - PTSD inducing experience to me
date: so I consider it time well spent. Yes
recommended:
it was so good I was ending some sessions of it in sweat and tired as after a workout. It was soo scary that at times I was just telling myself "It's ok... just skip it for tonight... will help you sleep better".

I repeat - this is a great game!

Tip:
2 things you might want to keep in mind
hoursPlayed:
since I realized them very late in the game and wish someone told me.

1 - Telekinesis... you can not only pull and swing and hold objects. But if you press fire button while holding something - you can shoot it forward.
2 - Green item boxes - YES you CAN open those. By stomping on them (sometimes there's enemy inside
voteText: but rare). So keep that in mind esp when you're playing on Hard. I did and realized it only at second to last chapter..."

my firends had jumped about 13 times and i remained calm determined to dismember any in my path.

By the end of my first playthrough I never once got scared.  I did however gain one of the most memorable stories from a game series.

Your resault may vary though.
9/10"

reviewText:
The fact that I replayed Dead Space now the third time in eight years should speak for itself.I succeeded in modding the game to be able to play it in 3840x2160 and after all those years it's still a visual treat.
Mechanics like zero gravity environments, vacuum, stasis and telekinesis add to the fun. Another good idea is the guidance indicator that shows the way to your next objective in the convoluted bowels of the USG Ishimura thus avoiding artifical lenghtening of play time.
Although for some players the game seems to have problems the only noticeable bug I experienced was a clipping error in the end fight. I got stuck in a tentacle and could not board the shuttle and had to do the boss fight again to finish the game.
The game is a steal for 10 € and even more on sale. I fully recommend it to everyone who likes scifi horror themed games and rate it 8.5 out of 10.

Dead Space 2 i hear fixes this problem but you do have it in dead space. I recommend the game since it a good price on sale, but sadly i got bored with the bad controls and fov very quick and didn't even feel like trogging through more of the same for a half dozen more chapters. reviewText:
When I first played this game, way back in 2009, it was one of the most incredible experiences I ever had. I completed it time after time in every difficulty. This week I decided to go back to it and it hooked me just like the first time.
Dead Space is one of those games that were ahead of its time, and today, 7 years after its release, is every bit as good as it always was.
Game developers nowadays (including this game's developer too, the money-sucking-leech known as EA) could use a lesson or two with Dead Space. This is how a game is done. There are no negatives and no setbacks, just plain fun.
So, if you haven't played this game yet, I highly recommend you to do so. Even if you're not a horror fan. Just... make sure to have a couple of spare underwear and pants at hand since you'll likely be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on those quite frequently. But in a good way, of course. If there is such a thing.

reviewText:
Since seeing the first advertisements for Dead Space, I knew I was going to love this game. And I was right.
It has all the right elements to making a good science fiction game: the lighting, a little bit of actual science thrown in for that hard sci-fi feel, the dirtiness of the environment, and of course, the creeping music.
The game was so dark and intense I found I had to take a break a few times per chapter and psyche myself up before going back in.
I heartily recommend this game for any fan of good, grungy science fiction and horror.

reviewText: I really feel like this game must be played on hard difficulty because medium just feels like a casual third person shooter, you get tons of ammo and the necromorphs are easy to kill. Hard genuinely feels like a survival horror game. The monsters feel like a real threat because they are challenging and you have to conserve your ammo which creates alot of tension during the fights. I don't think the game is scary at all however. The atmosphere and setting is great but the scares themselves i didn't find effective at all.\nI can think of two reasons why the scares don't work, guns and third person. When an enemy jumps out you have a way of defending yourself by shooting them so that vulnerability factor is lessened because of that. This is why games like amnesia and outlast work so well at being scary because you have no way of defending yourself. Even a game like Fear works so well, even though its a first person shooter the scares are supernatural and unkillable which is what makes it so effective. Because the game is in third person the monsters don't jump out in your face like they would in first person. The scares are at a distance from you because you are positioned behind the character you are playing. I don't think the game needs to be scary to work though it's still a great game because of its amazing atmosphere and sound effects and the game is just fun to play.\n8/10 (Great)

reviewText:
Dead frustrating

Okay, let’s get the bad out of the way first. The controls for the PC version of this otherwise good game are the worst I have ever encountered. I won’t go into detail but they’re so awkward they almost spoiled the game for me. Almost. (There are also some truly annoying problems with camera and viewpoint angles, but don’t get me started on that!) But what about the good? DEAD SPACE succeeds, despite the aforementioned problems, mainly because it oozes atmosphere. This is a very claustrophobic game that sucks you in and really does induce anxiety. You will jump many times, trust me. The story is okay, within the usual limitations of such games, the voice acting is uniformly convincing, and the graphics are good but not outstanding. Where this game excels is in the way it draws you in; immerses you in it’s dark atmosphere. This is a game that makes your palms sweat, which is exactly what it’s supposed to do.

3.5/5

reviewText: Ah yes, Dead Space.\nThis is one of my favorite series of all time, and if you decide to purchase this game, I think you may just find out why. Isaac Clarke is a futuristic engineer who is sent on a simple mission to repair a Planet Cracker vessel called the Ishimura. After a faulty landing, the crew finds themselves stuck on this ship, and the terrors ensue. This game set the base for survival horror when it first came out, and for good reason too. You will be on the edge of your seat with this one, and in the blink of an eye, flying into the back of it as well. I reccomend this game to all zombie loving survival horror gamers looking for an ingenious space age twist.

reviewText:
Awesome game. I wasn't really sure what to think of it when I bought it shortly after it came out. This series has become one of my all time video game favorites, and I have been playing video games for almost 25 years now.

Tips to enjoy:
1.) Turn out lights.
2.) Play at night.
3.) Be the only one home and expose your back to a large dark room.
4.) Get headphones with surround sound
5.) Enjoy peeing in your pants and jumping at shadows.


Seriously, this game is morbid, dark, twisted, and tons of fun. I keep going back for more.

The game may be old (2008ish), but is still lots of fun. Everything is done in 3rd person. This mean all interfaces, inventory screen, video/audio/text logs, maps, etc are shown in 3rd person at anytime where you can be attacked from mosters. The controls may seem unresponsive at first but it quickly adds to the game machanics and atmosphere and don't really become a burden. The lighting and sound design is spot on. That is where this game really, really shines. This game may not have the greatest graphics, but you couldn't ask for better lighting placement or sound effects. The game does mix things up and it never overuses a game concept which does add for atleast a second playthrough. Each enviroment feels different yet somehow familiar but you never get that feeling of been there

reviewText:
Dead Space: Succeeds where many other survival horror games fail. This game is brutal, bloody, and as hard as asteroid debris.
Pros:
+ Gore. You get a sense of dread in your stomach watching severed body segments float in zero gravity.
+ Challenging. You will die several times. Several times. You really have to want to beat this game to get to the end.
+ Long. It took me more than 17 hours to get through this game on medium, and that's pretty impressive for a game of this type.
+ Stage design is immaculate. Your objectives in each section are varied, tie in nicely with the story, and the game looks great on a nice rig.
+ The “Ripper” weapon is pure, unbridled joy.

Cons:
- The load screen makes you wait. If you try to minimize the screen and go do something else, it will still make you wait when you pull it back up. At least a third of the time you play this game you will be staring at the load screen. Ah, so this is how they meant to artificially extend playtime.
- Frustrating controls and camera angles. Why must I watch from his shoulder like a parrot? Oh, you didn't mean to hit that button? Sucks to be you. Hope you like staring at load screens.
- The protagonist is mute. When he gets ripped to shreds by Necromorphs, it's gross, but I feel no sense of connection to the hero.
- The asteroid-shooting mini-game is pure tedium.

Pro/Cons:
+/- The upgrade system is appreciated, but the changes you make to your gear don't always seem that significant.
+/- There is no cooperative mode, but then being the only person accomplishing tasks ramps up the tension.
+/- Objectives can be vague and will make you consult online guides, but then, this game doesn't always hold your hand. The stages aren't as linear as they are in the 2nd and 3rd installments, where you're carted along one path like a theme park ride.

Summary: This game is more than just Resident Evil in space. “Dead Space” does survival horror better. There is just a perfect amount of ammunition and supplies to keep you on the edge of your seat, amazing sequences, machines, and scenery, and it doesn't blatantly coddle the player. It qualifies as a classic.

Who should buy this game:
*Mature gamers that want a real survival horror challenge.
*Horror aficionados who feel that most games aren't gory enough.

Who should avoid this game:
*Gamers who want something to play with friends.
*Squeamish people that are upset by monstrous sounds, blood, and dead bodies.

I give it an 8.9 out of 10.

reviewText:
Probably my FAVE fps series of all time... or a pretty damn close tie. Dead Space is a BEAUTIFULLY made Horror FPS like no other. The series is packed full of gore, excitement, thrills and twists that will leave you to find yourself letting that pizza you just ordered get cold as you lean closer and closer towards your screen getting sucked into the nightmare that is Dead Space.

reviewText:
Buying the Humble Origin Bundle with the knowledge that 2/3rds of the Dead Space series was included, my feelings were probably akin to a royal food tester's: I love the banquet, but the thought of that one deadly dish is absolutely terrifying. I've played my share of Survival Horror (starting with the granddaddy of them all, Alone in the Dark), but there's just something about Dead Space that's truly terrifying - the same reason Amnesia still sits on my digital shelf collecting digital cobwebs.

But then the backlog starts piling, and a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do. I finished Dead Space, and that should count as something when I get to Purgatory. The worry of absolute terror never ended - that's really something considering the game clocks in about 12 hours; and most survival horror/action games usually lose the terror after a few hours of collecting heavy weaponry. I was hooked with the atmoshpere and story that borrows a lot from scifi horror greats, but somehow puts its own stamp of uniqueness on what it steals.

Speaking of uniqueness, there's a lot of it in Dead Space. The gameplay twist that enemies go down easier by shooting off their limbs instead of the head sounds wonky in the beginning, but a few encounters with the necromorphs made me a believer. It's perfect because arms and legs tend to move more erraticly than one's head, which adds to the tension when aiming. Also, as a result, probably the most unique weapons I've handled in a game were created for this Dead Space. The cutter, the linegun, the ripper, all have their special use when it comes to dismemberment, with just the right amount of frustration to give them character - give them a sense that these are real tools.

Another thing to note is the game's inventory system. Very much like Resident Evil's limited slot-based  inventory, complete with external storage nodes that transfer excess baggage from one spot to another, Dead Space ups the ante by adding money to the mix. This actually made inventory management fun instead of frustrating, as I was figuring out how much of which ammo I should have, I should sell in exchange for Power Nodes (basically upgrade points). It became a mini game in itself. I'd be sad to hear if this lead to the adoption of microtransactions in Dead Space 3, but for this humble begging, it's very much welcome. (It also helps that plot items have their own inventory space, so need to worry about not having a crucial item when you need it).

That's Dead Space in a nutshell. A rancid, mutating death nutshell. I'm still getting that same sense of thrill/dread about sampling the next two installments, so maybe I'll give the other gut-friendlier dishes in my buffet a try for the time being.

reviewText:
A true masterpiece. This game is a literally terrific combination of despairing emptiness, gory shootouts, and frigthening silence. It won't make itself impossible to play as Amnesia would, yet it will make you clinge to your chair and try to remember what on Earth made you start playing on the first place.

Some people had problems with the camera and mouse, but I haven't seen any of that. Even more, I love how the game is controlled, similarly to Mass Effect.

The lore is amazing, it will drag you and cry for more when it ends. Luckily there is more, by now. The art concept is sort of a crossover between zombie apocalypse"
recommended: which I love to no end.\n\nYou just can't go wrong buying this game."

reviewText: Ah yes, Dead Space.\nThis is one of my favorite series of all time, and if you decide to purchase this game, I think you may just find out why. Isaac Clarke is a futuristic engineer who is sent on a simple mission to repair a Planet Cracker vessel called the Ishimura. After a faulty landing, the crew finds themselves stuck on this ship, and the terrors ensue. This game set the base for survival horror when it first came out, and for good reason too. You will be on the edge of your seat with this one, and in the blink of an eye, flying into the back of it as well. I reccomend this game to all zombie loving survival horror gamers looking for an ingenious space age twist.

reviewText:
The first installment in the Dead Space series is set in the year 2508 and begins when a mining starship, the USG Ishimura, sends out a distress signal during a mining operation on the planet Aegis VII. In this game, players step into the role of Isaac Clarke ― a ship systems engineer whose journey starts on a seemingly routine mission to fix the communication systems on the planet cracker.

It is not long until he realizes that he stepped into a living nightmare of vicious alien creatures and a dead silence ship where he must constantly fight to get out alive.

The story in Dead Space is one of its strongest points. Most of it is told via video, audio and text diaries you find scattered around the ship. Another strong point is the atmosphere, a lot of it due to brilliant sound effects. It's a very impressive looking game overall, though sometimes you will feel like you are going through the same corridors over and over again. The combat is also good. Some sections may look a bit repetitive, however, the strategic dismemberment and the stomping are just extremely fun and satisfying.

Being a fan of the survival horror and sci-fi genres, I played this game myself and have watched other people play it, and it simply does not get boring. It does stop being truly scary after the first few hours but jump scares are always around the corner.

reviewText: This was probably almost a metroidvania during development, there's a lot of little things like the pointless mapscreen and often being able to tackle several objectives in any order (everybody just follows the breadcrumbs anyways) that point towards it. But even though that was a bust there's still lots to like here. the basic gameplay is very RE4 inspired but there's a lot to set it apart in the enemy design, and i think it puts an acceptable twist on the gun economy/inventory system compared to that game too. Cool gameplays, cool graphics, cool as hell setting, alright story. One of the few truly good 7th gen games, 9/10

reviewText:
I have had some mixed feelings about this game, but then again this happens for a lot of horror games I've played. I'm not a big fan of jumpscares as I feel them being a cheap way to enthrill. Then again I've played this game through 3 times and the reason for that is that this game has a very good gameplay. It has some mediocre issues in storytelling and atmosphere that prevents this being an outstanding game. Instead, this is just good.

I have played all parts of the series, except third installement is still uncompleted. Then again the third one didn't seem to have anything to do with the first one so I though I might as well review this now.

The plot of the game is pretty generic. In space no one can hear you scream. Weird monsters invade space ship and the protagonist must fight back after their immediate escape possibilities are cut down. Plot starts immediately and isn't very surprising at any point. Player travels back and forth in the ship doing stuff while other characters in the game stand still and cry. Kendra Daniels is one of the most annoying side characters I've so far seen or heard in a game.

The part where this game excels is that it makes the playing part fun, although the plot is uninsteresting. By giving the possibility to cut limbs instead of just shooting aliens, this game makes the fights somewhat more interesting and more pleasing. In a fight with multiple enemies, one can shoot their legs off before move to finishing them with another weapon. Also by making playable character a walker instead of a runner, the game is much better paced than some other horror games. Sure he can run, but he cannot shoot while running and running usually ends in a situation where a necromorph is close enough to hug Isaac.

Then again even though the pacing excels, this is yet another example where I think the game could've used a real director(like movies have). Though the game tries to be a horror game, it rarely excels in it. Most of the enemies are given away by loud roars or sudden violin sounds. Basically player just turns to where ever the sound came and shoots. Some jump scares are not enough to call it a horror game. It's a jump-scare-game. I'm not afraid of jumpscare, I just don't like them, like sewage. The game loses a lot of atmosphere by doing this. Games scaries part are the vacuum scenarios where no sound is played, so one must stay alert all the time for the enemy. Also there are occasionally so many enemies that I felt like playing a shooter instead of atmospheric horro game.

The game is really cheap today(2,5eur in sales) so no hurt trying. Easiest difficulty setting is enough to take any challenge out of the game if one feels like going it just for the story, although some atmosphere is lost by doing this.

To anyone suffering mouse problems, try V-sync out and force v-sync from video driver software or utilities like radeonpro. Also playable without v-sync but some say they've had problems related to one door not opening. Also playing without any kind of vsync might cause coil whine in gpu with FPS running over 200 with better cards(2012 enthusiast ->)

I recommend this game as a nice way to pass 8-10 hours, but don't expect anything great out of it. It's solid and it's good enough to give it a try. If you don't like it, don't buy the next installements either, they give nothing more.

reviewText: Dead Space is the classic definition of horror. This game made me feel so uncomfortable and disgusted, yet so attached and interested. It has a good story, filled with mistery and conspiracy. Everything about the game feels right and natural. It delivers a solid gameplay, which consists of exploring and fixing a huge ship, fighting an endless variety of necromorphs, playing with gravity, crafting and upgrading equipment, uncovering the truth about what happened, and just trying to survive. reviewText: This game has such a fantastic atmosphere. Stranded alone on a derelict station, you fight for your life against weird aliens. reviewText: Great game. Although not as scary as amnesia or cry of fear, the gun play and other various mechanics are excellent. The story is pretty basic but does have quite a few twists and turns. The ending is not that great, but I have yet to play the second and third game to make a final decision on that. It's a pretty long game too, I only played on easy and it took me 8 hours, plus you still have some replayability if you want to fully upgrade your weapons and whatnot. Overall the game gets a 93/100 from me, I can only hope the next two games are just as good, if not better.

reviewText:
Don't let my low hours fool you. I have played through this game a number of times on my Xbox 360, but since I've stopped using my 360 (but still wanted to play this game), I bought it on Steam.

Now, I thought I should address this issue first:

I have heard a lot of people complain about the mouse and keyboard controls in this game. My advice: buy yourself a wired Xbox 360 controller, download the drivers for it, and use that. Apparently bad keyboard/mouse controls aside, this game does feel like it was made for controller, and the controler settings are solid.

Now onto the actual game:

The Positives:

-- The story itself is good and I enjoyed it, but I felt like the story sometimes was a bit too far in the background (meaning I felt you were focusing purely on the objective and the story didn't really have much play in said objective). But overall, good story and despite the aforementioned, it was generally well implemented throughout the game. There are also twists, turns and little suprises that make it an awesome experience. Also, the ending was done really well!

-- The atmosphere is fantastic! The got the lighting right, the sound effects right, crew logs, everything! It was just done so right!

-- There are plenty of solid scares. There are some jump scares throughout the game and I know a lot of people hate those. But I'll be honest: jump scares really do work in this game.

-- The weapons are very well done; although there are some weapon and general game mechanics that really do lend the player to using the basic starting weapon throughout the game (not that this is necessarilly a bad thing).

-- Thought there is a realively straight forward (and argueably easy) way to play the game, there are so many other ways to play it. This ranges from weapons to the different modules (Stasis, Kenisis) to whether or not (and how) you use the object in the environment.

-- There is enough variety in the enemies to make it interesting, but few enough to keep the game consistent ( if that makes sense). and as  the above point suggests, there is more than one way to fight each enemy (with the possible exception of the boss fights). I was say the enemies are very well done and always fun to fight.

-- Boss fights are very well done, and the bosses are very cool!

-- I know this is techincally part of the atmosphere of the game, but it is definitely worth mentioning on its own that the got creepy right! A lot of horror games get jump scares and maybe a few solid scares down-packed, but they never get the creepy element right enough to actually be creepy. This game does, and it does it well!


The Negatives:

-- The thumb-stick controls can sometimes feel a bit slow. It does feel like it should be a bit more twitchy. That being said, the controls do work rather well, so this negative isn't all that bad.

-- Picking up items can be annoying in a select few situations. For example, an item maybe under a Stasis recharge point and instead of picking up the item, it will constantly engage the recharge point instead. That being said, there are other ways to pick up that item, but still....

-- Save points are not disabled during combat. Intead of picking up ammo during a fight that I desperately needed, the game instead activated the save point and I died. To be honest, this has only ever happened once (and I've done three run throughs of this game on normal and my third attempt at doing it on hard).


Overall, this dismemberment simulator is a very solid game with pretty much everything done right!

9/10

reviewText:
Dead Space
Being honest, I would say that Dead Space is like Resident Evil 4 in space with futuristic weapons. The atmosphere throughout the campaign accomplishs what its goal, scare the hell out of you, at least in your first playthrough. More that once I was suspicious about entering a room or walking near a corpse.

The graphics are pretty nice, considering its kind of an old game. I have played Dead Space only with the xbox controller, and the mapping, movement and aiming were really good; don't know about keyboard/mouse.

The sound quality is amazing, the background music or noises that you hear makes you turn around and check for any foe. Sometimes when you are shooting a necromorph, you hear some odd noises behind you, and then you realize you got another necromorph behind you D:

The boss battles were nice, the upgrading system with nodes, and the store had me hook up in having everything upgraded and bought.

I've played Dead Space like 6 times, and I do not regret it. It is totally worth your money. Btw, I beg your pardon if I've written something wrong, as english is not my first language.

reviewText:
So I just finished this game for the very first time...

What can I say...

It's a decent game, I think the best way to describe it is by saying it's mixture between RE and Doom.
The ending was a bit annoying before the last boss but once I reached him I had a blast again.

Graphics are pretty impressive considering when it was released.
Sound is really good too, play it with a headphone on and you'll feel really claustrophobic.

I bought the pack (Dead Space and Dead Space 2) and paid only 18 bucks for it, it almost seems like stealing.

Anyway, from 1 to 10 I'd give this game an 8.

reviewText: First of all the mouse sensitivity was all over the place. The camera wouldn't move and when it did it would move really slowly, making the game pretty much unplayable. I found a fix for that which still didn't work very well so I decided to play with a 360 controller. That worked fine but then I got to a door which I couldn't walk through because there was an invisible wall in the way. Apparently the first enemy in the game is supposed to come through it and start attacking you but that never happened. It seems a few other people have had this problem because I was able to find a fix which requires you to record with FRAPS while playing which will make the enemy appear and the invisible wall to disappear allowing you to progress.\n\nI don't know why I should bother playing any longer if I've already had this many problems in the first 5 minutes of the game. Luckily I got it on sale and only wasted a couple of dollars.

reviewText: SCARY. That is the short review. Since its been a while since I played it, that is the overrall tone of the game. You play as Isaac, an engineer who just can't catch a break. You go to investigate a ship that has gone dark and is in need of repair. Boy does it need repair. The game has jump scares which I don't find to be a negative because there is tons of others stuff that should creep you out. The ship is a character, as you piece the story together through various videos, documents, and audio journals. It is a creepy story. Also, you feel very alone. Even though you arrive with a small team, it quickly becomes apparent that no one can really help you. I like to think of the monsters as space zombies, and man are they freaky. Instead of the normal pop them in the head method, you have to take care of the limbs instead. There is a nice variety of weapons and armor to keep you on par with the nightmares you face. This is a game meant for playing after 10 PM with a good set of headphones. The ending is great and creepy and gets you ready for Dead Space 2. Even though it relies on shooting and blasting your way through, you will be on pins and needles the whole way through, wondering if your gun is enough to get you through in one piece.

reviewText:
I've always heard great things about this game, and the hype is right! I've finished the game and can barely wait to start the sequel!

It's an over-the-shoulder shooter (much like Resident Evil or Mass Effect), and the immersion is incredible. There's no HUD blocking the screen, ammo displays are on weapons and your health is displayed on the back of your character's suit. All the in-game menus (Maps, Inventory, Journal, etc) as well as video and audio communication are displayed with holographic projections from your suit. The game also has areas of zero-gravity where you must navigate your way by flying across the rooms, and hopefully not plunge into deep space.

The player takes the role of Isaac Clarke, an engineer and space ship systems specialist sent as part of a repair mission to the USG Ishimura, a large scale mining vessel. Upon arrival you quickly realize that disaster has struck the Ishimura and spend the game trying to get out alive. Throughout the game you can upgrade the space hazmat suit you wear, as well as buy and upgrade various weapons. The majority of the weapons you acquire are improvised tools, such as plasma cutters and buzz saws, reflecting that you're primarily an engineer, and not a soldier.

All in all it's a great buy; solid gameplay, a gripping story, and an incredible soundtrack. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
DEAD SPACE
Without a doubt this has been one of the most enjoyable FPS horror games I have ever played. Intense atmosphere and great jump scares make this game a thoroughly memorable experience. The Scfi genre generally lacks good horror games, but this game is worth every single penny.

Replay value: There is very little replay value since all the jump scares are scripted and predictable, however, new game plus makes for an interesting experience.

Final Verdict: Can you really say you are a respectable gamer until you have played this game? NO you cannot not. BUY IT! PLAY IT! You will love it or we will find you....

8.9/10

reviewText: This is an interesting trilogy so I had to start from the beginning. Although there are a few parts that make it feel like Dead Space: Prepare To Die Edition this is a great game. The weapons and powers are cool. Everybody thinks Resident Evil in space but it's actually got A 3rd person Crysis look also. The creatures are INSANE, better than Doom III. Whoever designed them, pure genius, just VERY cool. If you are a fan of 3rd person shooters, this is a must have game. If you are a fan of horror, this is a must have game. If you are a fan of both, like I am, then you will be VERY happy that you gave it a chance. The creatures, weapons, and innovative gameplay are what make this game SO worth every penny. Playing Dead Space 2 soon and will review as soon as I finish the game but I already know that it will be even better somehow. Dead Space 3 is the questionable one, I guess it is unavailable on Steam but I will have to at least give it a chance too when it goes down in price enough. I am a thrifty PC Gamer but this game was a smart buy!

reviewText:
Definitely a game at the very least worth playing.
Dead Space brings to the table elements of both survival-horror and RPG while maintaining a (third-person) shooter image.
The storyline is fairly well written as while it's nothign special, it works out and it isn't boring really.

The game itself is challenging but not in an attritional sense where it's only hard because of the sheer amount of enemies as opposed t the design and challenges itself. It's a hard game but not unfair (unless you pick that difficulty!). The gameplay is fluid and the battles are fun whilst challenging.
It's also a great thriller game, with many moments made to get you to jump in your seat.

Graphically speaking it's not a Crysis-level game but it still looks pretty damn good. The weapons and environemnts look nice, and the armour shines very well. You won't be disappointed.

Maybe not worth $50 any more, but with how differently you can play with the varying weapons and abilities, it definitely has some replayability. Try to pick it up when you can.

reviewText:
Freaking scary imo. Very nice atmosphere. Especially the sounds are really awesome and make me ♥♥♥♥ my pants. Bought it for 2,50€ and very happy with it.

The PC version has some problems which you can FIX easily. If you have too much Frames you will have bugs and the v-sync option ingame will make your mouse/joypad have a big inputlag.
I used the program nvidia inspector" and locked the frames at 73 (because i have a 75hz monitor) and activated v-sync through the program. With this settings the game works fine.
Also the ingame "antialiasing" option is very bad so activate it through "nvidia inspector". I have it on 8MSAA and it looks very nice.
Here some links how to fix the bugs (if you dont fix it you cant even get through the first door) and how to activate AntiAliasing.

AntiAliasing/Antistropic Filtering -->  http://forums.guru3d.com/showthread.php?t=357956
AntiAliasing/Antistropic Filtering -->  http://www.gargi.org/showthread.php?3609-Dead-Space-Antialiasing-auf-Nvidia-Karten-aktivieren

Bug fixing --> http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1725482

You are a horror and sci-fi fan and still have not played this game yet? Get it!"

reviewText:
This game is a crazy quest for revenge. You're Issac and you have a bone to pick with space itself.

You and your friends fly to space's home and start looking for space. While you're looking for space monsters attack but they're easy. I played on hard by accident and didn't even had to use cheat codes. I kill boss and then I see I can have 5 another guns? Way too easy. I thought.

But it had deeper meaning. As you go, killing monsters and looking for escape from space's home you're struck with a shocking revelation in an unpredicted twist of events that made my heart stop and my blood froze:

SPACE IS ALREADY KILL.

I have to say I've never would even consider this turn of the events, but then I looked at the title of the game and saw how deep the story was, you could even say the story was as deep as space itself and that wouldn't be an exgaggaration by one bit. This plot twist raises so many questions that make you think long after you finish the game. Who kill space? How will Isacc live without space? How did Isacc come to space house if space was kill all the time?

This game has taught me how pointless the revenge is and how we should be respectful basic elements of reality like space, planets or microorganisms.

Overall I give this game a score of 5 out of 6, 5 only because I was too scared to play after the plot twist.

reviewText:
I've always heard great things about this game, and the hype is right! I've finished the game and can barely wait to start the sequel!

It's an over-the-shoulder shooter (much like Resident Evil or Mass Effect), and the immersion is incredible. There's no HUD blocking the screen, ammo displays are on weapons and your health is displayed on the back of your character's suit. All the in-game menus (Maps, Inventory, Journal, etc) as well as video and audio communication are displayed with holographic projections from your suit. The game also has areas of zero-gravity where you must navigate your way by flying across the rooms, and hopefully not plunge into deep space.

The player takes the role of Isaac Clarke, an engineer and space ship systems specialist sent as part of a repair mission to the USG Ishimura, a large scale mining vessel. Upon arrival you quickly realize that disaster has struck the Ishimura and spend the game trying to get out alive. Throughout the game you can upgrade the space hazmat suit you wear, as well as buy and upgrade various weapons. The majority of the weapons you acquire are improvised tools, such as plasma cutters and buzz saws, reflecting that you're primarily an engineer, and not a soldier.

All in all it's a great buy; solid gameplay, a gripping story, and an incredible soundtrack. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Finished the game on Medium difficulty.

One of the best action-horror games I've played.

+Interesting story w/ good twists
+Great pacing - constant feeling of tension.
+Great sound - you will hear things you can't see, like creepy whispers, things crawling around, and creepy growls/shrieks.
+Great action - the dismemberment system is a lot of fun.  Forces you to carefully aim in tense situations.
+Feeling of progression - upgradeable equipment/armor.
+Little to no backtracking.

-This is a personal complaint, but a 180 degree turn like in the action Resident Evil games would've been helpful.
-Vsync forces 30fps.  I get about 350+ fps w/ vsync off with my gtx 970, causing horrible screentearing.  Vsync w/ nvidia control panel didn't work so I used D3DOverrider to force vsync at 60fps.  A small annoying step, but it's easy to do and IMO necessary to get the best experience.

+/- Graphics - played this 2008 game in 2014.  Sometimes the graphics look very good, sometimes it looks dated.  However, it never took away from the immersion.
+/- You might not like how much of the game is in a confined space. I liked it b/c it made things more tense.
+/- The field of view might be too limited for you.  I thought it was fine and never noticed it until I read complaints.

TL;DR - Buy if you want a sci-fi game that scares you, but still gives you the power to kill everything.

reviewText:
Buy this game.  Play it at night, alone.

The first half of this review is a defensive measure against all of it's haters and critics here on Steam.

Notice how all the negative reviews have either or both of two complaints: 1) the game doesn't run well, or 2) the controls suck because the port sucks. These people never thought to realize that maybe, just MAYBE, it's not the game that doesn't run well but it's their PC that doesn't run the game well. NEWSFLASH: If your PC blows or is outdated then you have no room to complain when a game any more demanding than Minesweeper runs poorly. There, I said it. Next up, the controls do suffer a bit at first but alas, we are humans, and we overcome and adapt to a new control scheme and feel for new games. Or at least some of us. Seriously, within an hour the controls felt fluid and fine. Unplayable" they said. Seriously guys? Every game has a different feel
date: so why are you complaining about the mouse acceleration. Some people say it takes several seconds to turn around 180 degrees... Maybe turn your sensitivity up higher than 1%? I can turn around and have my gun drawn in less than half a second. These same people probably don't have the other half of their brain to even appreciate that slightly clunky controls actually makes this game better. Allow me to elaborate: You're Isaac Clarke
recommended: a man looking for his woman
hoursPlayed: stuck in a massive planet cracker starship infested and overrun with an unspeakable danger. You're scared. You're outgunned. Outnumbered. MAYBE
voteText: JUST MAYBE
helpfulPercent: having a "slow" response time and realistic movements makes the game feel better because it adds to the desperation and hopelessness of the atmosphere of the game. Not being able to instantly whip around or aim perfect head shots in 0.0065 seconds makes the game scarier. It really does. It takes away your control. It makes you feel like you are in just as much control of your situation as Isaac is
votesHelpful: which isn't much. Having to take an extra half second to gain your bearings and wait for your body's momentum to stop in order to aim at your targets neck actually makes the game feel real and much more human. You feel vulnerable
votesTotal: and THAT is exactly why the controls and the feel of them make the game FEEL scarier.\n\nWith that said
votesFunny: this game is a masterpiece. I loved it. It mixed many different aspects of good storytelling

and I don't have money for it. Dilemma: Spend all of my hard-earned credits on a new suit and be bankrupt or spend it all on enough ammo to get to the next chapter? The struggle is real gentlemen.

I'll stay here where I'm safe and you go get 20 parts scattered across the ship with dozens of cannibal necromorph creatures that desperately want to chop your legs and face off in order to restore power to the ship's components so that we can repeat it all over again in the next chapter." I guess you have to go with this formula but it still got a little old in the way the tasks were presented.

reviewText: I'll be honest and admit that I failed to get into this one on the PS3 some years back, mostly on account of the controls being too unweildy.  But on PC this game frigging ROCKS.  Like any great horror game, the sound design is the single most effective element, and keeps you on your toes constantly...at least until the last quarter or so of the game, by which time things do become a mite predictable.  But apart from being a tad overlong for its own good, this is pretty well a must-play for anyone who loves the Silent Hill and/or Resident Evil franchises, or similar third person horror games...it's by and largely a remake of Resident Evil 4 set in space, if you want to be pedantic, but fresh enough for all that.  Story and setting-wise, its influences are more noticeably cinematic, namely 2001: A Space Odyssey meets Alien by way of John Carpenter's The Thing.  All exceptionally good company, in other words!  Spooky, fun, stupidly violent...all the things any sane person demands in a video game.  Looking forward to the next two!!!\n\nVerdict: 9.5/10.

reviewText:
Definitely a game at the very least worth playing.
Dead Space brings to the table elements of both survival-horror and RPG while maintaining a (third-person) shooter image.
The storyline is fairly well written as while it's nothign special, it works out and it isn't boring really.

The game itself is challenging but not in an attritional sense where it's only hard because of the sheer amount of enemies as opposed t the design and challenges itself. It's a hard game but not unfair (unless you pick that difficulty!). The gameplay is fluid and the battles are fun whilst challenging.
It's also a great thriller game, with many moments made to get you to jump in your seat.

Graphically speaking it's not a Crysis-level game but it still looks pretty damn good. The weapons and environemnts look nice, and the armour shines very well. You won't be disappointed.

Maybe not worth $50 any more, but with how differently you can play with the varying weapons and abilities, it definitely has some replayability. Try to pick it up when you can.

reviewText: The first Dead Space takes place on one large spaceship on a general forward path with the ability to return to a few hubs to unlock more rooms, very much like a deliberate Resident Evil in space, with the doomed spaceship taking place of the haunted mansion. The aliens are evolved versions of The Thing, mutating dead flesh into gross killing appendages. Its easy to write off Dead Space as any number of influences mashed together, but it continually strives to be more, with extra care taken to make certain room entrances and boss queues unpredictable.\n\nYes, its Resident Evil + The Thing + Event Horizon + Aliens + Metroid, and other source material, but its the best parts all wrapped up in one.

reviewText: For what it's worth, it's not much of a horror game. It's one of those adventure shooters that has ugly enemies. Whenever you pass by vents or see necromorph corpses that hasn't been disfigured, you'll already know that they're just there for jump scares. I will give points for the creepy atmosphere and all the bloody, organic rooms will give you chills. Bosses are also great, even though there's only three. The first one you encounter will let you use one of the game's mechanics of zero gravity jumps to dodge tentacles which makes you seem VERY cool and badass. The second one, I didn't enjoy much since I suck at aiming and then there's the gun overheating. The third and last one was actually a let-down compared the first one, which you'd expected it to be more of an overkill, slightly surviving with a slither of HP. The only thing good that came out of the last boss was how it picked you up and you were forced to use inverted controls to make you panic than you usually would. Then there's the storyline. I feel the twists were from an M. Night Shyamalan movie. You can already foreshadow what'll happen and the twists wouldn't really amuse you. It'll just give you sense of saying, Welp
date: more work to do.". Character developement are pretty bad. All you know about the protagonist is that he's here on an adventure to find his girlfriend and slowly becoming loopy while not knowing about it. Really
recommended: the only thing that comes out of the storyline is the lore and backstory and most people who comes to shooters just want to use their itchy trigger-fingers and kill everything on sight. All-in-all
hoursPlayed: this game is just a generic shooter from Point A to Point B. It's a great shooter from its time I'll agree to that; however

reviewText:
Dead Space relies very heavily on jumpscares and shocking imagery for it's horror. Don't get me wrong, it can certainly get quite tense every now and again, but it never really starts to feel like a 'Survival Horror' game as the game is fairly generous with both ammunition and health. Unless you're playing on higher difficulties you're probably not going to find the game all too challenging to be honest.

That being said, Dead Space ironically excels at one of the aspects often done poorly in horror titles: It's combat. Almost every weapon in your arsenal is viable in any situation, giving you some very refreshing freedom to find a playstyle that suits you. The violence and gore is definitely also satisfying for those of us that enjoy watching limbs come flying off. The voiceacting is solid and the soundwork in general is very tight.

You are very rarely (if ever) bored while playing Dead Space as you'll find yourself utterly immersed in it's great combat almost all the time, except for when the game gives you a break, typically in the form of exposition-sequences or fairly decent puzzles. While you don't have to be a math student to get over these hurdles they can definitely throw a spanner in the works every now and again.

7/10 - Complete with a compelling story with a few surprising twists along the way I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes gore, violence and a character that controls like a tank. The only real downsides to this game I can think of off the top of my head is perhaps the slight lack of challenge, the unreasonably confusing map, and the fact that it has some severe issues with Mous/Keyboard controls. A gamepad is strongly recommended for this title.

reviewText:
I have one word for this game. AMAZING.

Dead Space is truly a horrifying game but a really fun one too! I'll just get straight to the pro's and con's, so you know what is right and wrong about this game!


PROS:
-The atmosphere for the game is just PERFECT! It mostly consists of Dark rooms with smoke/fog filled with dead bodies/blood. It is a very spooky game, which always keeps you on the edge of you're seat.

-The ambience for the game once again is SO GOOD! You'll hear random screams, sometimes there will be sounds around you as if there is something crawling through the vents which just overall gives you LOTS of chills. It feels like anything could happen at anytime.

-The fact that you are pretty much alone in this HUGE space ship filled with zombies/aliens really gives you the chills, and its just a perfect concept.

-I really love the node system, how you find/buy nodes and can upgrade you're suit, weapons, or the stasis stuff you're suit has (I'll let you discover that on you're own!). Upgrading certain things really does make you feel stronger. I rememebr playing through this game once, hardly even upgrading any guns, and because of that, I looked at certain parts as a challenge, when the next time I played through the game, I tried my best to upgrade my weapons and health, which made those frustrating parts before such an easy task!

-I LOVE the enemies. They truly are super freaky, especially when you have multiple enemies coming at you once, from different directions. Their screams, their looks, they are seriously the perfect enemies for a horror game like this.


CONS:
-There are really NO cons other than how sometimes the level designs can feel repetitive after awhile. That and, after fighting the enemies for a couple of chapters, they start to lose their spooky feeling, but they are still a big challenge to kill.


FINAL SCORE:
10/10

Regardless of the small cons the game has, the game continues to be what it was truly meant to be, a horror/action game. and for the first time ever, I can say that EA did a great job! After beating Dead Space, I feel like I am now a true fan of the series, which is why I just HAVE to play the others.

reviewText: Very good game that looks and plays very well after 7 years have passed. The horror element is pretty constant while not going stale. The only bad thing about the game I've heard is the controls, but I got used to them very quickly and found that to be a nonissue. My favorite thing about this game is the amount of ways that you can die, which made death a bit less frustrating and a bit more fun. The game also has a pretty novel fighting system, where it often makes sense to dismember enemies before killing them which I haven't seen to the same extent in any other games. Very recommended.

reviewText:
I heard so many good things about this game before I played it. Everywhere I've seen I mentioned, everyone seemed to be completely in love with the game. I don't honestly see why.

Why not?
The game is honestly incredibly boring. Now. I love my survival horror games but I couldn't see what was so special about this game. The only scares were jump scares. Sure. The atmosphere was pretty decent but it didn't help me that the game pretty much told me when I should be scared. Early scare cords, the lights going out, plentifiul ammo. Not once did I actually feel like the game was pressuring me. I haven't played the second yet but I can't see why I would. I'm pretty much in the minority here but I honestly think the third game was a lot more fun. People complained that it removed the horror from the game but I ask. What horror?

I feel like this game series would be so much better if it were to be just a straight up action game. Three was fun because of the co-op and gun creation mechanics. Things felt unique and interesting. I could kill things with a shotgun boozka or a revolver with a giant blade on the end of it with friends. Sure. That's a completely different game then this one but a much more enjoyable one at that. Take the good things from this game, the art style. The atmosphere. The unique monsters and put it into a better done genre then this.

reviewText: There is a bug that ruins the whole game for me.! I am on chapter 7 and have been playing on Hard difficulty. reviewText: There is a bug that ruins the whole game for me.! I am on chapter 7 and have been playing on Hard difficulty. What the bug does is that arbitrarily it will set the difficulty to normal whether you are paying on Easy or hard. Basically the only option that works is Normal the other two difficulties are broken. I searched and found a certain fix using a certain tool to edit the save file. It doesnt work it only renames your save file as hard but the gameplay will always be Normal. And when you save again the difficulty will just be Normal as always. This simply is not acceptable, so be aware that when you buy this game Normal might be your only option. This is my 2nd playthrough and I have experienced this twice.

reviewText:
Below was the first part of my review.  I have since managed to make it into the game.  And while it is still nothing compared to part 2, It is at least worth playing so you can get a little more of the story.  However this one won't be played a second time.

On a lighter note though.  The Leviathan was done very well.

Picked up the game because somebody mentioned it was the Alien game we've been waiting for.  If only that were true. Within the first 2 hours of play I was so unimpressed I doubt I will finish the game.  First off I don't know why they made it so you looked like a hunched over monkey when walking.  Second the creatures were not impressive and the weapons were even more lame.  I think I would give the flamethrower the award for most useless weapon of all time in any video game created.   The fights were predictible with little surprise.  Walk 10 feet have something drop down in front of you, shoot the leg and arm and it dies.  Rinse. Repeat.  Another thing,  I don't  understand why people think that just because you paint all the walls with blood it makes the game spooky.  It is very cliche' and not very imaginative.   So I guess what I'm saying is I would not recommend this to anybody unless they were utterly bored and this were free.

reviewText:
Not many horror games use space as the backdrop and the few that do, usually do so with raving success. Dead Space is part of that. It's terrifying, but like any scary game, the longer you play it, the more desensitized to the fear you get. That and paired with the fact that you eventually (should you choose to) upgrade your weapons to a high degree usually means the monsters that scare you die in embarassing fashion.

The method is in which this game does go out to scare you is cheap as well. There are a lot of jump scares and set pieces. Any time you enter a large enough room, you know there will be an ambush. Eventually, you can start predicting when the scares happen. Monsters come out through vents and the predictable blind corner will usually have one waiting for you. Vents are scattered throughout the ship you're stranded on, so when you instinctively feel like an ambush is going to happen, it's easy to set yourself up and defend the waves.

Good game overall. Scary games of this type should be shorter though because you can feel that the developers themselves know that you're no longer scared so what they'll do with ambushes is just increase the waves, turning what's supposed to be scary into a full blown shoot out with paced rumbles that can sometimes last longer than you have patience for.

The Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star rendition was sp00ky though.

reviewText: I passed on buying this game when it first came out because it looked a bit odd. It wound up in my library through a HumbleBundle, and I decided to give it a play. I instantly regretted passing over this game all those years ago. The gameplay is great. Getting used to the control scheme and view point is not automatic, but it quickly becomes second nature. Characters are well thought out, and are developed excellently. Im a big sucker for a good story in video games, and Dead Space absolutely delivers. The story is fleshed out, and develops nicely as the game progresses. The atmosphere is excelent. I cannot stress this enough, the game keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The environment is littered with potential threats, keeping you constantly scanning. The designers didnt stop there though. They paired this trecherous environment with a weapon" collection that some how just never has enough ammo
date: and a character that just cant ever get his hit points back up to full. Exhaustive scavenging and ammo conservation are essential to success
recommended: but then that just loops back to an environment that is trying to kill you 100% of the time. All in all
hoursPlayed: the game is absolutely amazing

reviewText:
To be short , its a great game if you like space horror.

The graphics are awesome the lighting effects are stunning.
It has plenty of weapons you can buy or upgrade which is very nice. Upgrades are also applied to armor.

1 tip im giving is a little tweak because of the horrid mouse controls ( lag , dead points , low sensitivity ) if you encounter these go to your APP DATA folder C:\Users\USER\AppData\Local\Electronic Arts\Dead Space and open the settings.txt in the bottom line just paste the following :

Control.AimAssistEnabled = false
Control.AimingPosition = 0
Control.ControllerSensitivity = 2
Control.DeadZone = 0
Control.FireButtonControls = true
Control.InvertX = false
Control.InvertY = false
Control.MouseAcceleration = 0
Control.MouseSensitivity = 2.00000000
Control.Shock = true
Controls.AcL.X = 0x1104007E
Controls.AcL.Y = 0x00030008
Disable Vsync from nvidia control panel or something else and you're done.


The game is straight forward and the story just adds to the atmosphere. With 2.5 hours played i give it a 8/10 i might think higher of it though as i progress.

reviewText: The second I started playing this game, I knew that it was special. This game perfectly blends quick responce and beutifuly smooth combat with a suspensful, scarry and well designed atmosphere. The enemys in this game are downright terrifying, and the story is awesome. The game has a linier campain, but is packed full of Bioshock-like RPG elements. The scarres in this game are real, not just popout stuff (although there are quite a few popouts), and it is one of the gorriest games I have ever seen! Even for being about eight years old the graphics are astounding. Like I said, the story is really good, it keeps you going in a great way, something that not a lot of games do. The voice acting is on point, from the chracters you meet, to the audio logs you find in lockers.  If you ever get stuck somewhere you just hold down B and a blue line shows you where to go, and you can check Isaac's commentary/journal if you are still lost. The entire game is in third person, which I did enjoy. This game is so fun, this is something that all gamers should experience.  If I were to rate it, I would totally give it a 10 out of 10, this game is a masterpiece and deserves every bit of the praise and populartiy it gets. If you have the money, buy it.
