reviewText:
Throughly enjoyable game. Vague story that unlocks more as you play and pick up text and audio logs.
The biggest problems I have are as follows:
1: Not scary. Never once during this game did I shout in horror or scream in fear as a monster popped out of a grate. I mean, you KNOW they're coming out of the vents because an audio log tells you so.
2: Mouse lag. This is a big problem, but it can be fixed turning on Vsync on your GPU, not in the game.
3: Plasma Cutter beats all. There is no better weapon.
But overall, its a solid game. The dismeberment aspect of the game, needed to kill the monsters in the game, is something I haven't seen in an another game ever. Graphics are pretty good, but occasionally spotty graphics.
I didn't find the monsters a challenge on Normal difficulty (I have yet to play the game again on a harder mode). Never died once to the Necromorphs (monsters). I did die a ton of times to the enviroment though.

reviewText:
Buy, rent, try, or pass?
I'd say this (given what's likely an aged price-tag) is a game to add to most collections.
Buy.

My one big con for DeadSpace: unresponsive controls.
My list of pros: The cinematic quality of the portion I've played is astounding. Nearly unparalleled. I'm almost happy to give up some control responsiveness for how gorgeous and immersive this game is. You have to play it to understand. And if you're the least bit adventurous, in the middle of the night with some nice headphones, in the dark. The jumpscares are great! I think this game made my little brain go DIE!DIE!DIE!KILLITWITHFIRE!!!" more than any other game before it. But lemme say something again
date: the movement and punch/kick controls are terrible. Like I said
recommended: I'm ALMOST happy to give up some control responsiveness

reviewText: A masterpiece of survival horror. In my opinion, it feels like the true successor to the old Resident Evil games (RE 1,2,3,CV) for plunging the player into a constant state of unease by utilizing sound effects, environmental cues, and deprivation of resources to the nth degree (for first timers at least).\n\nIf you haven't played this game yet, you truly are missing out.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to be in a sci-fi space horror movie? If so, then Dead Space is for you.

The best aspects of Dead Space are the sound, music, and overall solitary/frightening mood the game sets. There were several occasions where I found myself turning around because I heard something echoing in the distance… sounding as if it was coming closer. Even the zero gravity heavy steps you take sound fantastic with a hollowed, deep bass sound. When the environment is right and the audio is incredibly well done, you have a great setting for a game.

The biggest downside of the game was the linear story line. You get a few options of which upgrades you would like to make to your gear but really, you will only want to use 1 maybe 2 guns as some are very weak and pretty much useless. The character development is bland as well. Do not play Dead Space looking for a great story because you will not find it.
The gameplay may also feel stiff at first, even for a third person shooter but it kind of makes sense. You are in a heavy space suit, your mobility should be limited. To counter this, the gun controls are tight and precise. You can really feel the power of them (especially once upgraded).

Even with the nearly non-existent story, the environment really immersed me. Play the game, take your time going through it; do not rush it. 8.5/10
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A totally awesome game.
When Resident Evil quitted survival horror games, Dead space should totally be your choice. This game packs action, horror, survival, and a very nice story. It kinda gets repetitive when you are almost finishing it, (i wont enter details to not spoil) but if you dont mind that. I barely got anything to complain about the game, I personally had no bugs nor glitches, except from one fps problem wich made my mouse lag, in the start you wont pay a lot of attention to it, but when you progress it will start to feel waaaaaay too annoying to let it be... once you fix that, the game can be played as any other. Very nice graphics for the time it was made, sound could've been improved, very AWESOME story, with lots of information of what's going on before your arrival, you can see the progressive madness that the crew of the ishimura had, how did it start, who or what is responsible for it, it is simply very awesome. Isaac could've been a more... how to say it... memorable character, I dont like mute characters, but i can really make an exception on Isaac, the game lenght is very nice I would say that it can be won on 13 to maybe 15 hours on normal difficult, you can replay to see if you got most of the audiologs, and to maybe try another difficult, or just a different weapon combination.
Graphics: 8/10
Sound: 7/10
Story: 10/10
Gameplay: 8/10 With no bugs on my playthrough
General score: 8.5 (for regular people) 9.5 (for survival horror fans)

reviewText: Well... was it worth $5? Yes. But not more than that. Sure the violence is over the top, the weapons are unique, and there are a few legitimate scares. reviewText:
First off, bad port, or bad quality control. Whatever you call it. Graphic quality is ok, but ♥♥♥♥ poor optimization ruins the game. Still playable though.

Control is no good either. You can't possibly remap, in-game, buttons as freely as you want. Your mouse's side buttons can't be mapped. Really unhappy with the awkward button mappings by default either.

Game definitely isn't 86/100. 70/100 to be more precise. The good side of the game is the true scare factor.

Anyway, worth playing if you like horror game. Well, it's less than a dollar game, after all (humble bundle ahem). If you plan on buying on Steam, buy DEAD SPACE PACK. Trust me, worth it for DS 1 + 2. Too bad DS3 isn't here.

reviewText: Players step into the boots of Isaac Clarke, a systems engineer that's part of the dispatched maintenance crew. Outside of fixing the communications issues, Isaac has a number of reasons for arriving on the Ishimura -- he has a number of friends that are stationed on the ship, including someone very special to him that sends an urgent holovid with a few cryptic messages before she disappears. Unfortunately for Isaac and his crew, shortly after they arrive on board the crippled vessel, all hell breaks loose. Their craft is destroyed, leaving them stranded on the Ishimura. The crew is attacked by nightmarish creatures known as Necromorphs, who kill most of Isaac's team and separate him from the surviving members. Even worse, the ship and its systems have started to be corrupted or are failing thanks to the Necromorphic infestation. It's up to Isaac to wander the halls, search for any friends or survivors that are still alive, and fix as many problems as he can until he can find a way to escape the ship, which can take you 12 or more hours to complete.\n\n- Jeff Haynes (ign.com) -

reviewText:
Someone please convince me to continue playing this. I know this is considered a horror classic by now, but I just can't go on. I finished the first chapter, but I'm so very bored and uninterested.

It seems like a really bad PC port. The camera never shows you the monsters surrounding you and the controls feel incredibly clumsy. It's like after years of evolution in the FPS space, we suddenly decide that it would be 'more challenging' with an eyepatch and our hands tied together.

A boring story and hodgepodge of game mechanics, together with the screwed-up controls just result in zero immersion for me.

Although I feel a bit better about just putting it down after rewatching the ZP: http://www.escapistmagazine.com/videos/view/zero-punctuation/333-Dead-Space

reviewText: Just played for half an hour.  Looks like a great game, but don't buy it on PC (you can try if you have a joystick) - it is too frustrating.  The controls are horrific - and I;m not very picky.  If you set mouse sensitivity on max in game and in your mouse settings, you stil can't turn around in less than 40 sec!  This is in a horror action game where you have to react or die.  You can't run and turn, you can't turn around while still, you can't look around very well and the camera angles get mighty annoying.\n\nOh, one more thing - two minutes into the game you get your first weapon and get stuck!  It's an invisible door that is a known bug - searched the internet, changed my v-sync, still couldn't fix it.  Check out the issues online before you buy.  CONSUMER BEWARE!

reviewText:
Do NOT buy unless you are really really willing to fight the controls. It's a diabolically bad console port that just fails at understanding a mouse. (Even without vsync)

The game itself isn't that bad, got all the right aspects of a horror game, just not compiled correctly. The result is a pretty average FPS with about 0 scare value beyond the first 10 minutes. It seems like all the effort went into the intro.

Most of the levels suffer millions of go-grabsomething-comeback syndrome, even when you ignore that every level starts and ends on the same tram system used to get around the ship. Also suffers major voice-in-ear syndrome. The lack of variation makes it a very tedious slog to finish.

Only buy Dead Space if you're prepared to destroy your wrist and if it's at a rediculous steam sale price.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Dead Space seems to be having an internal design war between horror and action, and neither side wins. The better action gameplay is made frustrating by ineffective scares, while nothing in it, save one noteworthy enemy, is ever actually frightening. The story is inititally boring, with plenty of incoherent audio logs, but late in the game briefly coalesces into something interesting before completely collapsing into an insult of an ending.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Disappointingly un-terrifying. After the first couple of fights with a necromorph they stop being scary. Sure there are plenty of jump-scares, but due to the terrible pacing you get desensitized to them pretty quickly. Full of plot-holes, bad characterization, completely unoriginal story…

Honestly the best thing about this game was the sound design. The atmospheric bangs and clangs of necromorphs running through vents above you, roaring in the distance, orchestral stings and satisfying gun sounds add a lot to what is otherwise a very bland gaming experience. Unfortunately a lot of the sounds seem to be in low bitrate, which is a shame.

It’s also a lot of fun to dismember necromorphs with the plasma cutter. If it wasn’t for the terrible mouse controls I’d be hard pressed not to recommend this game just for that.

reviewText:
An alright game, but a bad PC port, so I can't recommend this. Bottom line is that without some out-of-game tweaking, you won't be able to tolerate playing this game.

reviewText:
Through out this I am going to make a lot of comparisons to Resident Evil Remake and Alien Isolation, because I want to show you that games made 6 years BEFORE this game and 6 years AFTER this game nailed an oppressive atmosphere with nowhere near the amount of jumpscares as this game.

The Spencer Mansion in Resident Evil Remake certainly had scripted jumpscares, the dogs through the window the second time you went through, the zombies through the window, the hunters through the windows. LOADS of windows. But, it still would have a terrifying atmosphere even without those scares. Just the fact that it gave you about a magazine for every 3 zombies and that you could kill about 2 zombies with 1 magazine meant that you had to find your way around zombies, which meant dodging around them or taking a longer but safer route around the mansion. THAT is survival horror.

But Dead Space, which clearly takes inspiration from Resident Evil Remake, (because what survival horror doesn't?) doesn't take things like the atmosphere. I mean sure, it has scary moments, even when enemies aren't there, but that's just because I'm afraid something will jump out and a loud musical sting will play. I'm not scared of the ship, or the monsters, I'm scared of the musicians slamming there hands down on the piano again.

Alien Isolation, a game that came out in 2014, last year, go 'it'. How to do survival horror without unscripted jumpscares, and having an oppressive atmosphere. The bit when you walk through the synthetic bay, where all the dying 'Working Joe's' go to die. You walk through a corridor with about 10 'Working Joe's' standing idol, and you just know that if you turn your back they'll throttle you, but they don't until 10 minutes later when the game throws 8 shotgun shells, 3 flares, 2 medkits and 6 revolver bullets at you, but that's besides the point.

I do not think that this is a bad game, I just don't think it's a good one either. It takes the claustrophobia and 'survival horror' from RE:R and A:I but they seem a lot clumsier here. Sure you may love this game, but I'll stick with the good stuff until EA get this right the fourth time round.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The sound design and weapon design are both top notch but every other part of the game is mediocre to downright bad. The games few high points come in a few clever environmental puzzles and a few fights where you have room to maneuver and aim. Unfortunately, there's a lot of just boring traversal and extremely cramped fights where you just dump ammo to avoid getting stun locked and killed. The story is very poorly written and told, it tries to be immersive but there's just no depth to it and the game tries to pull multiple twists that don't even make sense or carry any weight. The final boss fight might be the most frustrating part of the game as there's a lengthy unskippable cutscene at the start AND an even longer unskippable cutscene if you die.

Add to all that, you need to tweak the game to even use the mouse like a mouse and no FoV and the game is exceedingly awkward at times. I played with a controller and the sensitivty was either too high for precision or too low to move and turn efficiently. I didn't feel the game was more suspenseful due to the controls, it just felt poorly made. This was especially prevalent in bossfights and certain sequences when you were grabbed and had to free aim while being jerk around. I died a number of times because both your firing point AND the spot you're shooting are snapping around with no fluidity at all. Certain enemies have animations where they're invincible and you have to wait for them to snap to another animation for them to be vulnerable again which looks awful and is tedious.

The only way I would recommend this game is if you absolutely love suspense/horror as everything else it tries to do is done better somewhere else.

reviewText:
It's OK, I guess. Unlike its sequel, which I enjoy wholeheartedly, I find this one to be not so very gratifying. You spend a fair hour doing one big main objective to keep the ship working and survive, and then on completion, you get a quick pat on the back and told to move on to the next big objective, where as in the second Dead Space, the game feels like it's progressing, like you're getting somewhere. It feels good!

And also, contrary to popular belief, the game becomes a lot less scary in the first 10 minutes of the game. It's all practically jumpscares, and after the first one (which I did almost ♥♥♥♥ myself), I found the rest of the jumpscares, which is again, THE WHOLE GAME, to be really annoying. They just wore my patience very thin. I bought the game to be afraid, not to be given a surprise party I expected every five seconds!

In conclusion, the game is OK, and maybe you would find it worthwhile buying it in the Dead Space complete pack when it's on sale, as Dead Space 2 was a pretty worthwhile purchase to me.

reviewText:
I would love to say that this game has all you want from a space-bound horror story. That at times it reminded me of System Shock 2. That I would never be able to dream of space without dreaming of this game, but...

And this for me is a major but,... but this game is unplayable for Logitech peripheral users, this includes myself (I own a nice shiny G13 gaming keyboard and a H360 headset ). My 1.5 hours in-game were mostly spent watching the intro cutscene (please, no more, I don't need to hear how Issac's ex needs to speak to him, I've heard it too many times now), whilst waiting to see if my changes have stopped the camera panning to the top left, spinning me around and around and around.

The final nail is that the game was developed and published by EA, so once you've paid for your shiny game, forget about any support other than transferring your Steam version to Origin for every problem (seriously, I did try asking for help, hoping EA would have improved since being named the worst American company - Consumerist Magazine, but this was their only suggestion each time).

Basically, if you own Logitech peripherals or expect support from the developer, don't buy this game.

Okay, that's my rant over this game done, thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Do NOT buy unless you are really really willing to fight the controls. It's a diabolically bad console port that just fails at understanding a mouse. (Even without vsync)

The game itself isn't that bad, got all the right aspects of a horror game, just not compiled correctly. The result is a pretty average FPS with about 0 scare value beyond the first 10 minutes. It seems like all the effort went into the intro.

Most of the levels suffer millions of go-grabsomething-comeback syndrome, even when you ignore that every level starts and ends on the same tram system used to get around the ship. Also suffers major voice-in-ear syndrome. The lack of variation makes it a very tedious slog to finish.

Only buy Dead Space if you're prepared to destroy your wrist and if it's at a rediculous steam sale price.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Dead Space seems to be having an internal design war between horror and action, and neither side wins. The better action gameplay is made frustrating by ineffective scares, while nothing in it, save one noteworthy enemy, is ever actually frightening. The story is inititally boring, with plenty of incoherent audio logs, but late in the game briefly coalesces into something interesting before completely collapsing into an insult of an ending.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Disappointingly un-terrifying. After the first couple of fights with a necromorph they stop being scary. Sure there are plenty of jump-scares, but due to the terrible pacing you get desensitized to them pretty quickly. Full of plot-holes, bad characterization, completely unoriginal story…

Honestly the best thing about this game was the sound design. The atmospheric bangs and clangs of necromorphs running through vents above you, roaring in the distance, orchestral stings and satisfying gun sounds add a lot to what is otherwise a very bland gaming experience. Unfortunately a lot of the sounds seem to be in low bitrate, which is a shame.

It’s also a lot of fun to dismember necromorphs with the plasma cutter. If it wasn’t for the terrible mouse controls I’d be hard pressed not to recommend this game just for that.

reviewText:
Avoid the game is not very good.

The game is boring and completely fails as a horror game.

The plot is a rip off mix of Event Horizon and Aliens. Your time would be better spent just watching those films and save you half of the game play.

The most entertaining part of this game is that Issac has his wife working on the ship and all the characters keep telling you that:
A: Issac is worried
B: We should feel sorry for him.
However, this complete fails as Issac is a mute with a bucket on his head and completely unable to show emoution. I laughed so hard when her fate was shown as the big emoutional scene completely fails.

The second game has a short 3 min vid you can sit through which is a catch up of the plot from the first game (a far better use of time than playing through the first game).

Still I bought both for £5.

reviewText: This is a prime example of what happens when developers stop developing for PC and make games targeted for consoles only.  It is a game that wants to be System Shock.  It is filled with all the obligatory suvival horror tropes even down to monsters coming out of walls, harsh shadows, monsters playing dead, and the requisite jump scenes.  What it fails to deliver is gameplay that is actually any fun.  It starts well, and brings in neat features like zero-gravity, time-dilation, and telekinesis.  However, In short order managing those features, and their related resource constraints, becomes just another chore.  All this is even get past the absolute worst part of this game: the nonresponsive controls that just scream Nerfed for Console Use".  I wouldn't spend more than $15 for this one."

reviewText:
The number of inventory slots you have isn't enough to carry sufficient ammo from one Store to the next. I was running out of my bullet-based guns every time.

Also, it seems like they had a real-time inventory just because they could. They don't even let you sprint when using it, so the only time you can use an invntory item is when there aren't enemies around. This means no stasis recharge and no oxygen recharge when you really need it. More realistic you say? It's the lack of realism that makes games fun. Get slashed once and die like you would in real life, then see if you like realism.

Almost didn't complete this because the Store is real-time as well, so I couldn't resupply when there were enemies around. Just had to run for it. it means I couldn't complete the last part of the game which required guns, and I had to download an invincibility hack.

Well worth its £3.00  =]

reviewText: The second I started playing this game, I knew that it was special. This game perfectly blends quick responce and beutifuly smooth combat with a suspensful, scarry and well designed atmosphere. The enemys in this game are downright terrifying, and the story is awesome. The game has a linier campain, but is packed full of Bioshock-like RPG elements. The scarres in this game are real, not just popout stuff (although there are quite a few popouts), and it is one of the gorriest games I have ever seen! Even for being about eight years old the graphics are astounding. Like I said, the story is really good, it keeps you going in a great way, something that not a lot of games do. The voice acting is on point, from the chracters you meet, to the audio logs you find in lockers.  If you ever get stuck somewhere you just hold down B and a blue line shows you where to go, and you can check Isaac's commentary/journal if you are still lost. The entire game is in third person, which I did enjoy. This game is so fun, this is something that all gamers should experience.  If I were to rate it, I would totally give it a 10 out of 10, this game is a masterpiece and deserves every bit of the praise and populartiy it gets. If you have the money, buy it.

reviewText: Players step into the boots of Isaac Clarke, a systems engineer that's part of the dispatched maintenance crew. Outside of fixing the communications issues, Isaac has a number of reasons for arriving on the Ishimura -- he has a number of friends that are stationed on the ship, including someone very special to him that sends an urgent holovid with a few cryptic messages before she disappears. Unfortunately for Isaac and his crew, shortly after they arrive on board the crippled vessel, all hell breaks loose. Their craft is destroyed, leaving them stranded on the Ishimura. The crew is attacked by nightmarish creatures known as Necromorphs, who kill most of Isaac's team and separate him from the surviving members. Even worse, the ship and its systems have started to be corrupted or are failing thanks to the Necromorphic infestation. It's up to Isaac to wander the halls, search for any friends or survivors that are still alive, and fix as many problems as he can until he can find a way to escape the ship, which can take you 12 or more hours to complete.\n\n- Jeff Haynes (ign.com) -

reviewText: In space, no one can hear you scream -\n\n- or so went the tagline for a certain film set in space on a ship where things go terribly wrong a million miles from Earth. It's a classic game; dark, moody, dripping with the creeping terror that seeks your flesh as you trudge through the halls of the doomed USG Ishimura on a repair mission gone awry. The voice acting is superb, and the visuals are excellent even though the game is over 5 years old. It's a must-have for sci-fi horror fans, and a great game in general.

reviewText:
Throughly enjoyable game. Vague story that unlocks more as you play and pick up text and audio logs.
The biggest problems I have are as follows:
1: Not scary. Never once during this game did I shout in horror or scream in fear as a monster popped out of a grate. I mean, you KNOW they're coming out of the vents because an audio log tells you so.
2: Mouse lag. This is a big problem, but it can be fixed turning on Vsync on your GPU, not in the game.
3: Plasma Cutter beats all. There is no better weapon.
But overall, its a solid game. The dismeberment aspect of the game, needed to kill the monsters in the game, is something I haven't seen in an another game ever. Graphics are pretty good, but occasionally spotty graphics.
I didn't find the monsters a challenge on Normal difficulty (I have yet to play the game again on a harder mode). Never died once to the Necromorphs (monsters). I did die a ton of times to the enviroment though.

reviewText:
The transition of survival horror took the meaning of horror in a different direction, wIth Resident Evil 4, we moved from the overall feeling of dread and suspense in the previous titles, to a more generic jump-scare type of horror (with maybe its exception of regenerators). Resident evil 4 was by no means a horror masterpiece, but it was campy and fun, and its gameplay was fantastically implemented, with set pieces oozing from it's pores to thrill the player.

Dead space tried (and failed) in my opinion to bring back any of that tension. Instead we have a linear set of sequences filled with scripted jump scares from monsters overdesigned to look horrific.

There's only a few times of note worthy moments in this game. One in particular was when you enter a room full of dead bodies, and later the game loops around to this room, except now it is populated with a monster which can make monsters from corpses. I had never encountered this monster before I found this room the first time. I instinctively dismembered all of the corpses, and when I came back around it paid off, instead of a dozen monsters I only had to deal with one. That was a moment of rewarding the player for actually playing the game in a way a video game should be played, trusting the player to emergent decisions as opposed to leading them down set routes with set expectations of play. It did that moment once.

So much potential wasted as well. It would have been a lot better if it was more open, Metroidvania. It had the capacity to do that since we have the floor system. And the scripted jump scares could have been randomised or intellegently coded AI which could determine a best attack when the player is at their weakest.

In short, this series is overhyped garbage.

reviewText:
Dead Space is a great example of a game that puts you on egde. It never truly scares you, but it certainly makes you raise your guard constantly knowing that despite your best paranoid efforts, a necromorph will still startle the crap out of you from behind. Being locked in a room with twenty enemies and low ammo certainly puts you through a major stress test.

When it comes down to it, I personally believe Dead Space 1 was the pinacle of Dead Space gameplay. Isaac didn't say anything, and the environment fit perfectly in place with what it was supposed to be: An abanadoned, infested space station. Your two allies only called every now and then, so as to not oversaturate the game with dialogue and let you focus on absorbing the atmosphere and enjoying the awesome limb-splattering combat system.

The combat system is nearly sheer perfection in terms of feeling. Every shot from most weapons can seriously pack a punch when upgraded, and there is nothing more satisfying than shooting somebody so hard all their limbs fly off or their head explodes. Every enemy was satisfying and fun to fight, with the exception of the f*cking Guardians, which felt like a cheap gimmick at first and always turned into a chore.

The story is pretty weak at best. It all comes down to Isaac basically repairing the entire space station then attempting to retrieve The Marker"
date: which he fails at as well. Thankfully
recommended: once I really started playing I didn't even care it had a bad story anymore. The gameplay was addictive and multipaced: going from slow to incredibly fastpaced in mere seconds. This more than made up for a horrible story.\n\nAt the end of the day

reviewText: Port Doom 3 to the consoles, then port it back to PC with non-rebindable controls and a laggy mouse, and the result is Dead Space. The game starts out in the survival horror vein, but soon suffers an identity crisis, locking the player in arena-like spaces with dozens of fast moving monsters attacking at once, which is dubious considering that the character is as agile as a pregnant potato and takes up at least a third of the screen. Choosing a third-person perspective for a game with a silent protagonist is another strange design decision that removes any sense of immersion, especially when the character just stands over a dying woman like a manikin with no trace of emotion. Add highly repetitive and mostly predictable gameplay involving completing two to three objectives per level, some of which are recycled later on, and there is no surprise that Doom 3 ends up a far superior game, with near identical visuals and storyline, but no artificial handicaps, better immersion, action, and horror.

reviewText:
Dead Space is without a doubt an epic masterpiece, and I'll tell you why:

Set in outer space, this horror action shooter puts you in the role of somebody without any military background (you are and engineer) who has to fight for his life as he tries to figure out what happened inside the vessel you were sent to fix up, while some unidentified hostile specimens try to gut you.

The cutscenes and dialogues are special as they introduce you to the background of the Ishimura (the vessel you are at) as intriguing you why everything's so suspenseful and uncertain, you really feel like you are alone to fight for your life in every corner you take, every door you open, and pretty much every step you take. The ambient musicl is marvelous, as well as the enigmatic and frightening fog and dark, creepy lights in every room or corridor you happen to be at. You will never know what's coming up next (ok, after some hours you might already guess that a wave of specimens is gonna spawn, but trust me, even if guessing, that doesn't takes the panic away. You have to fight them back after all), and overall this game feels like you are in the main role in a sci-fi horror movie, as everything is so atmospherical you actually believe you are Isaac Clarke, it's so inmersive and deep (I recommend playing this at night with a decent volume level btw) that as the story progresses and you begin to know facts about this strange outbreak you really want to keep playing to finally unveil the truth behind your mission, everything's surrounded with mystery even 'till the end. An Instant classic that you don't wanna miss out. Oh and don't forget to play on the highest difficulty, the game will get even better as you will appreciate your ammo and health packs to a higher degree, all this to achieve the ultimate survival experience.

My personal score 92/100

reviewText:
1 of my favorite games on xbox 360. I put many hours in and played the full story on each difficulty. DS1 is my favorite of the 3 DS games.

PC dead space feels like a bummer because 1 minute of gameplay i get to the room where you obtain your first weapon and a bug prevents me from walking through the door. As explained on a couple cite-able resources, the game is poorly ported and can either have too much fps because vsync is off, or not enough fps because vsync is on.

I wouldnt recommend this game because this issue has apparently been going on since this game was available for pc and takes troubleshooting to operate as expected.

I will cite a couple sources to support this

http://steamcommunity.com/app/17470/discussions/0/846962626952252891/
http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2671623

reviewText:
Have tried everything to fix the vsync bug, including going into my catalyst center and forcing vsync while turning it off ingame.

This is game breaking since its a choice between seeing or being able to fight.

Vsync off: Can move, black bars cover everything

Vsync on: Can see, controls have about 2 seconds latency.

I need to find a fix, this shouldn't of been allowed to remain in the port.

And even if I fix that, then the first door after getting the cutter is STILL bugged and wont let me through.

Don't get me wrong, i played this on console, i know this is a badass horror cornerstone game, but this port simply is not working.
